The report shall show the name and address of each retail dealer, the quantities delivered to each retail dealer, the amount of excise tax collected under the terms of this division, and such other reasonable information as may be requested by the city. The report shall be accompanied by remittance payable to the city for all taxes collected or due, as shown on the report. 
( Ord. No. 504A, Exh. A, 5-18-2017 ) 
Sec. 8-206. - Noncompliance by wholesale dealer; distributor. 
If any wholesale dealer or distributor fails or refuses to make the reports required herein, the city shall notify such dealer or distributor in writing and if the reports are not made and the taxes, penalties and interest are not remitted within five days from the date of delivery of such notice, such wholesale dealer or distributor shall be prohibited from making any further deliveries in the city. 
( Ord. No. 504A, Exh. A, 5-18-2017 ) 
Secs. 8-207—8-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PER DRINK 

Sec. 8-221. - Levy and collection of excise tax. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed and levied upon every purchaser of alcoholic beverages by the drink within this city a tax in an amount equal to three percent of the purchase price charged to the purchaser for such drink. 
(b)  Every licensee or his agent is hereby authorized and directed to collect the tax imposed herein from purchasers of alcoholic beverages by the drink within the licensed premises. Such licensee or agent shall furnish such information as may be required by the city to facilitate the collection of the tax. 
(c)  In all cases where the collection of food and drinks is by deferred payment or credit, the licensee is liable at the time of and to the extent that such credits are incurred in accordance with the rate of tax owing on the amount thereof. The city shall have authority to adopt rules and regulations prescribing methods and schedules for collection and payment of the tax. 
( Ord. No. 504A, Exh. A, 5-18-2017 ) 
Sec. 8-222. - Reports and remittance. 
(a)  The tax imposed by this division shall become due and payable from the purchaser at the time of purchase of any mixed drink in this city. All amounts of such taxes collected by the licensees shall be due and payable to the city monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period for which the tax is imposed; provided, however, that upon a proper showing that the tax imposed will not be collected until after a regular billing period of the collecting agent then the collection of the tax may be deferred by the city for an additional period not exceeding 30 days. 
(b)  On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the city in such form as the city may prescribe by every licensee liable for the payment of tax hereunder. All returns shall show the gross receipt of the sale of distilled spirits by the drink and the amount of tax collected on such drinks. 
(c)  Copies of the "summary of sales" showing delivery by each supplier to consumption on the premises licensees shall be furnished to the city clerk with each monthly payment. 
(d)  Licensees collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state tax under the Georgia Retailers' and Consumers' Sales and Use Tax Act, approved February 20, 1951, as now or hereafter amended (O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq.). 
( Ord. No. 504A, Exh. A, 5-18-2017 ) 
Chapter 11 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Power of local governments to license, regulate and tax billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 11-1. - Title. 
This chapter shall be titled and known as the Amusement Machine Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 2, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Amusement machine means every machine of any kind or character used by the public to provide amusement or entertainment whose operation requires the payment of or the insertion of a coin, bill, other money, token, plate, disc, slug, ticket, or other similar object and the result of whose operation depends in whole or in part upon the skill of the player, whether or not it affords an award to a successful player pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35, and which can be legally shipped interstate according to federal law. Examples of amusement machines include, but are expressly not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Pinball machines; 
(2)  Console machines; 
(3)  Video games; 
(4)  Crane machines; 
(5)  Claw machines; 
(6)  Pusher machines; 
(7)  Bowling machines; 
(8)  Novelty arcade games; 
(9)  Foosball or table soccer machines; 
(10)  Miniature racetrack, football, or golf machines; 
(11)  Target or shooting gallery machines; 
(12)  Basketball machines; 
(13)  Shuffleboard games; 
(14)  Kiddie ride games; 
(15)  Skeeball machines; 
(16)  Air hockey machines; 
(17)  Rolldown machines; 
(18)  Pool tables or billiard tables; and 
(19)  Any other similar amusement machine which can be legally operated in the state. 
Amusement ride means any mechanical device, other than those regulated by the Consumer Product Safety Commission, which carries or conveys passengers along, around, or over a fixed or restricted route or course or within a defined area for the purpose of giving its passengers amusement, pleasure, thrills, or excitement. The term "amusement ride" shall not include any such device which is not permanently fixed to a site. 
Area of operation means the territory located within the corporate limits of the city. 
Billiard room means any public place where a person is permitted to play the game of billiards and for which a charge is made for use of equipment. One billiard table may cause the operator to be considered as operating a billiard room. 
Billiards means any of the several games played on a table surrounded by an elastic ledge of cushions with balls which are impelled by a cue and shall include all forms of the game known as carom billiards, pocket billiards, and English billiards. 
Distances means the area between the premises where amusement machines, amusement rides, billiards, music amusement machines, or video poker amusement machines, or any combination thereof, are operated and any school, college, church, or funeral chapel; provided, however, any other provisions of this chapter notwithstanding, such distances from churches and funeral chapels shall be measured between the church or funeral chapel and the structure on the premises, or the part of the structure on the premises, where amusement machines, amusement rides, billiards, music amusement machines, or video poker amusement machines, or any combination thereof, are operated. 
Exempt machines means every machine of any kind or character that is not included within the definition of an amusement machine and shall include, but is not expressly limited to, the following: 
(1)  Coin-operated washing machines or dryers; 
(2)  Vending machines which dispense products or services for payment of money; 
(3)  Gas and electric meters; 
(4)  Pay telephones; 
(5)  Pay toilets; 
(6)  Cigarette vending machines; 
(7)  Coin-operated scales; 
(8)  Coin-operated gumball machines; 
(9)  Coin-operated parking meters; 
(10)  Coin-operated television sets which provide cable or network programming; 
(11)  Coin-operated massage beds; and 
(12)  Machines which are not legally permitted to be operated in the state. 
Gambling device means any contrivance which, for a consideration, affords the player an opportunity to obtain money or other thing of value, the award of which is determined by chance even though accompanied by some skill, whether or not the prize is automatically paid by the contrivance (but not including those machines which afford an award to a successful player pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35). 
Minor means any person younger than 18 years of age. 
Music amusement machine means every machine of any kind or character used by the public to provide music whose operation requires the payment of or the insertion of a coin, bill, other money, token, plate, disc, slug, ticket, or other similar object. Examples of music amusement machines include, but are expressly not limited to, jukeboxes or other similar types of music amusement machines. 
Person means any individual, corporation, partnership, joint venture, association, trust, unincorporated organization, or other entity and shall include any other person that has a substantive interest in or effectively controls such person as well as the individual officers, directors, general partners, trustees, or other individuals in control of the activities of such person. 
Premises means the space or area owned, leased and/or controlled by any person and used by said person for the purposes of operating amusement machines, billiards, video poker amusement machines, amusement rides, or musical amusement machines, or any combination thereof. The term "premises" may also include one physically identifiable place of business consisting of one room or two or more contiguous rooms operating under the same trade name, ownership, or management. 
Video poker amusement machine means every machine of any kind or character used by the public to provide amusement or entertainment whose operation requires the payment of or the insertion of a coin, bill, other money, token, plate, disc, slug, ticket, or other similar object and the result of whose operation depends in whole or in part upon the skill of the player, whether or not it affords an award to a successful player pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35, which can be legally shipped interstate according to federal law, and which by way of a videotape, videocassette, video disc, prerecorded video display or visual depiction simulates the play of a poker card game. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 3, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-3. - Regulation of the operation of amusement machines. 
Every person operating amusement machines within the corporate limits of the city, including music amusement machines, billiards, video poker amusement machines, and amusement rides, but not including exempt machines, shall only operate said machines in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The regulation as set out in this chapter is necessitated by the potential abuse of minors due to their fascination with said machines and also by the easy use of said machines as gambling devices. Therefore, said machines shall only be operated within the corporate limits of the city in accordance with this chapter. In assessing the need for proper regulations, the city council has determined that these proper public concerns, except as for billiards and video poker amusement machines, do not require as much regulatory oversight when only one amusement machine or one music amusement machine is in operation on a premises. The city council finds that the operation of more than one amusement machine on one premises or the operation of a gameroom, or both, holds a special attraction for minors who are not as capable of exercising good judgment as adults and, therefore, necessitate regulation by the city. Further, the city council finds that billiards and video poker amusement machines are extremely susceptible to being used as gambling devices and also require regulation by the city. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 4, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-4. - License required. 
Every person operating an amusement machine, a music amusement machine, a billiard room, a video poker amusement machine, or an amusement ride, or any combination thereof, shall be required to obtain a regulatory license from the city for the operation of said machine (including, but not limited to, a billiard table) within the corporate limits of the city. Application for such regulatory license shall be made to the city council upon a form to be supplied by the city clerk for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 5, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-5. - Qualifications for regulatory license. 
(a)  Initial application. Every person that applies for said regulatory license as required by section 11-4 shall be at least 21 years of age and shall make application on forms furnished by the city clerk or other properly designated agent of the city council, and in connection therewith shall, under oath, answer all questions, supply all information, and furnish all certificates, affidavits, bonds, and other supporting data as required thereby. In all cases where the person operating the amusement machines, music amusement machines, billiard room, video poker amusement machines, or amusement rides, or any combination thereof, is a resident individual, the application shall be made in the resident's name. Where the operator of said machines (including, but not limited to, a billiard table) is a corporation, partnership, association, or nonresident, the application shall be made in the name of an officer, partner, or associate who owns a substantial interest in the business or in the name of the principal managing officer or agent and the application shall show that the license is for the use of the person operating said machines, and the person shall be named. The written application for the license shall be a permanent record which the licensee must maintain current as required by subsection (a)(1) of this section. Failure to maintain a current license application as required by this section shall be grounds for revocation of same. The following provisions shall apply: 
(1)  No person shall have, own, or enjoy any ownership or interest in, or share in the profits from, or otherwise participate in the operation of amusement machines, billiard rooms, music amusement machines, video poker amusement machines, or amusement rides, or any combination thereof, within the corporate limits unless a full description of such interest shall have been furnished to the city council at the time such interest arose. It shall be the duty of the licensee to report to the city council within five days any change in any interest in such licensee's business including, but not limited to: 
a.  Any division of the profits; 
b.  Any division of net or gross sales for any purpose whatsoever; 
c.  Any change in the payment of rents or leases; 
d.  Any change in the ownership of any lease or building or land used in such business; 
e.  Any change in the ownership of any corporation that has any interest in such business or the change of management of such corporation. 
(2)  After receipt of such notice, the city council shall notify such person within a reasonable time of any objection to the ownership or interest set forth therein, and it shall then be incumbent upon such person to dispose of such interest within 30 days after the mailing of notice to do so by the city council to such person at his address as shown on such notice of interest. In the event such interest is not disposed of within 30 days after the mailing of notice by the city council, or in the event no objections are filed within said 30-day period, or in the event such person fails to notify the city council of the transfer of any such interest within 20 days after the acquisition thereof, the license as provided for herein may be revoked by the city council until disposition of the interest has been made or notice given to the city council of the transfer. 
(3)  The report required by subsection (a)(1) of this section shall be in the form required by the city council and shall be an amendment to the licensee's permanent license application on file with the city council and, as such, shall be under oath and verified as otherwise required of license applications. 
(b)  Renewal application. The city regulatory license issued shall be valid only for the calendar year indicated thereon. A licensee that desires to continue in business during the next or subsequent calendar year must make a renewal application for such year on or before November 15 of the preceding year. All applications for the renewal of licenses shall be treated as applications for new licenses, except that they need not be advertised (where required). Payment of license fees for renewal of licenses may be made at the time of application or by December 31 and, upon approval of renewal by the city council and payment of the regulatory fee, the license will be issued or resurveyed. The following conditions shall apply: 
(1)  No city regulatory license may be transferred from one person to another or from one location to another without permission and approval of the city council upon written application made. Approval as to any change shall be at the discretion of the city council. 
(2)  Each application for transfer of a license shall have attached thereto a completed copy of any notice of change of interest required by the state revenue commissioner. After receipt of such application, the city council shall notify such applicant within 20 days of any objection to the transfer as set forth in the application. Said license shall remain in effect pending approval of the transfer. Upon proper application, the city council may permit the license to be transferred upon payment of the regulatory license fees required under section 11-8. Upon the death of any license holder, his personal representatives or his heirs may continue to operate under said license for the balance of the year without the payment of any fee, if otherwise qualified as license holders, or the license may be transferred to a qualified transferee within 30 days after condition of the estate of the deceased licensee will permit, upon payment of the transfer fee. 
(3)  Any licensee desiring to discontinue business at one location and commence business at some other location must make a complete new application for such location. 
(c)  Denial of application. When contrary to the public interest and welfare, no license to operate amusement machines, music amusement machines, amusement rides, billiard rooms, billiards tables, or video poker amusement machines, or any combination thereof, shall be issued by the city council to or for: 
(1)  Any person, as determined by the city council by reason of such person's business experience, financial standing, trade associations, personal associations, record of arrest, or reputation in any community in which he has resided, who is not likely to maintain the operation for which he is seeking a license in conformity with federal, state or local laws, rules and regulations; 
(2)  Any person who has been convicted under any federal, state, or local law of any felony involving moral turpitude; 
(3)  Any person who has been convicted under any federal, state, or local law of any felony not involving moral turpitude within ten years immediately preceding the filing of application of such license; 
(4)  Any person convicted under any federal, state, or local law of a misdemeanor, particularly, but not limited to, those involving misuse of amusement machines, misuse of video poker amusement machines, misuse of billiard tables, gambling devices, alcoholic beverages, gambling, or tax law violations, if such conviction tends to indicate that the applicant will not maintain the operation for which he is seeking a license in conformity with federal, state, or local laws, rules and regulations; 
(5)  A location at which the operation of the proposed business would be in violation of the zoning ordinances of the city; 
(6)  A location at which a previous regulatory license has been revoked or suspended and where, in the judgment of the city council, the problems which have arisen from the operation of a license at such location indicate that it is not in the interest of public health, safety, welfare, or morals that said machines or billiards, or any combination thereof, be operated at such location; 
(7)  Which the granting of such license would constitute a violation of state law or regulations. 
(d)  Written notice of denial. Before the city council shall deny any application for a license or for the transfer of any license, or shall revoke any existing license, the applicant or licensee, as the case may be, shall be given notice in writing from the city clerk to show cause before the city council at a time and place specified not less than three days nor more than ten days from the date of service of the notice why said application for license or for transfer of license should not be denied or why said license should not be revoked, as the case may be, stating the grounds therefor, and at the appointed time and place the applicant or licensee shall have an opportunity to show cause, if any exists, why said application should not be denied or said license revoked, after which the city council shall take such action as it, in its judgment and discretion, shall deem warranted under the facts. The hearing herein provided for need not be at a regular meeting of the city council but may be at such time and place as shall be fixed in said notice. All decisions denying, approving, suspending, or revoking any regulatory license or application shall be in writing with the reasons therefor stated and mailed or delivered to the applicant or licensee, as the case may be. In addition, at any hearing as provided herein, the party afforded the hearing shall have the opportunity to present evidence and cross examine opposing witnesses. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 6, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-6. - License applications; contents and terms. 
(a)  Contents. All applications for said regulatory licenses shall be made in person by the applicant to the city clerk or any other properly designated agent of the city, in writing on forms furnished by the city. The applications shall be signed by the applicant and shall contain, but not be restricted to, the following statements and information: 
(1)  The name, age, address, telephone number, and length of residency of applicant. 
(2)  The name, location and description of the premises of place of business which is to be operated under such license. 
(3)  A statement of whether the applicant, or any person with an interest in the application, has made application at any previous time for a regulatory license from the city or any other governmental entity for the operation of amusement machines, music amusement machines, video poker amusement machines, billiards, or amusement rides, or any combination thereof, and the disposition of such application. 
(4)  Whether the applicant, or any person with an interest in the application, has ever been convicted of a crime, other than traffic violations. 
(5)  A description of each machine (including a billiard table) to be covered by the regulatory license, the mechanical features of said machine, the name of the manufacturer of said machine, and the serial number of said machine. 
(6)  Whether a previous license of any type issued to the applicant, or any person with an interest in the application, has been revoked by any state or subdivision thereof or by the federal government, and the reason therefor. 
(7)  Whether any other person is to be interested directly or indirectly in the profits or losses, or both, of the proposed business. 
(8)  No regulatory license for an amusement machine, a music amusement machine, billiards, video poker amusement machines, or amusement rides, or any combination thereof, shall be issued to any person unless the building in which the business will be located is complete; detailed plans of said building and outside premises are attached to the application; and an occupancy permit for these premises to be licensed has been approved and issued by the proper agent by and for the city. The completed building shall comply with the building code of the city and any regulations of the state. Each building in which the business is to be located shall contain sufficient lighting so that the building itself and the premises on all sides of the building are readily visible at all times from the front on the street on which the building is located so as to reveal the inside retail area of the building and so as to reveal all of the outside premises of said building. Each applicant for said license shall attach to his application evidence of ownership of the building or a copy of the lease if the applicant is leasing the building. 
(9)  All new applications for said regulatory licenses shall be accompanied either by lawful money of the U.S. or by a certified check or cashier's check, payable to the city, for the proper amount of the regulatory license fee. In the event the license is refused, the regulatory license fee shall be returned to the applicant, except for an administrative charge of $20.00 to cover the administrative costs of processing the application incurred by the city. 
(10)  The financial responsibility of every applicant for a regulatory license shall be shown to the satisfaction of the city council. Each applicant shall submit a complete statement of his financial condition with the application. 
(11)  Every applicant for said regulatory license or transferee of such license and every employee of applicant, upon hiring, that will work or perform duties on behalf of the applicant within the corporate limits of the city shall be fingerprinted by the city police department, the county sheriff's department, or other properly designated agent of the city before a license is issued hereunder. Said fingerprints may be submitted to any proper law enforcement agency to verify the information contained within the application. In addition to the set of fingerprints submitted hereunder by the applicant, the applicant shall also furnish a complete set of fingerprints which shall be forwarded to the state bureau of investigation or any other proper law enforcement agency. Should the fingerprinting check reveal that any information contained within the application is false or misleading, the city shall have the right to revoke the license granted to the applicant upon receipt by the city of the information learned from the fingerprinting submission. 
(b)  Notice. No application for said regulatory license shall be acted upon by the city council until after the applicant has run a notice of said application in the newspaper in which legal advertisements are run for the city for at least four different days prior to the meeting at which said application is to be presented and considered. Said notice shall contain the name of the person for whom the application is submitted and the name of the person applying, if different, and the location of the proposed business. This notice shall not be required from an existing regulatory license holder making application for the renewal of an existing license at the same location. 
(c)  Untrue or misleading statements. The making of any untrue or misleading statement in the application for said regulatory license shall be sufficient cause for the refusal, suspension, revocation, or cancellation of such license as the city council shall deem proper. 
(d)  Expiration. All said regulatory licenses shall expire at midnight on December 31 of the year in which issued. 
(e)  Fees. The regulatory license fees for which provision is made in section 11-8 are due and payable immediately. Any person who is doing business or begins to do business at any time after January 1 and before July 1 shall pay the full annual regulatory license fee. Any person who begins to do business on or after July 1 shall pay one-half of the annual regulatory license fee. 
(f)  Surrender, revocation before expiration. No regulatory license shall issue for less than a calendar year or remainder thereof subject to the provisions of subsection (e) of this section, and in case of the revocation or surrender of such regulatory license before the expiration of such calendar year, the holder thereof shall not be entitled to receive any refund. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 7, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-7. - Short-form applications; contents and terms. 
(a)  In the event the applicant is seeking a regulatory license for only one amusement machine, music amusement machine, or amusement ride, the application shall be made in person by the applicant to the city clerk or other properly designated agent of the city council, in writing on forms furnished by the city, signed by the applicant and contain, but not be restricted to, the following statements and information: 
(1)  Said applicant shall provide the same information as required by section 11-6(a)(1) through (7). It is the intent of the city council that where only one amusement machine, one music amusement machine, or one amusement ride is to be operated by the applicant, the applicant need not provide a financial statement to the city council, nor submit detailed plans of the building or structure (although the building must still meet the city building code), nor submit to any fingerprinting as a part of the application. 
(2)  Further, an applicant who may properly submit a short-form application also shall not be required to run any notice of said application in the newspaper, as set out in section 11-6(b). The short-form application shall contain all of the other information and statements as required by section 11-6 and shall be subject to all of the other terms and conditions as set out by section 11-6. 
(b)  An applicant for the operation of only one billiard table or one video poker amusement machine shall be required to submit a regulatory license application pursuant to section 11-6 and have said license contain all of the contents required of such applications under section 11-6 and meet all of the terms and conditions of section 11-6 and all other requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 8, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-8. - Regulatory fees. 
(a)  As a part of its exercise of its police power and as a part of or as an aid to regulation of said amusement machines, music amusement machines, billiard rooms, video poker amusement machines, or amusement rides, or any combination thereof, every applicant shall pay an annual regulatory license fee before being granted a regulatory license, in accordance with the schedule set out herein, for the privilege of operating said machines (including billiard tables) within the corporate limits of the city. The amount of said regulatory fees approximates the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city which includes, but is not limited to, the review of the operations of the applicant to be sure that said applicant complies with this chapter and that the applicant is not using or permitting the use of said machines as gambling devices or for gambling purposes, or both. The regulatory license fees which shall be paid by the applicant shall be as established by the city council from time to time. 
(b)  The city council finds that the regulatory license fees assessed for each video poker amusement machine and each billiard table are necessary due to the intensive regulatory activity necessitated by said machines due to the easy use of said machines as gambling devices. Further, due to the nature of billiards and video poker amusement machines, besides being extremely susceptible to being used as gambling devices, said machines are also extremely susceptible to being repeatedly played as gambling devices to the detriment of the user. For these reasons, the regulatory fee is higher in an attempt to offset the regulatory expense incurred by the city in ensuring that the machines are being properly used for amusement and not as gambling devices. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 9, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-9. - Gambling devices not permitted. 
Amusement machines, music amusement machines, amusement rides, billiard tables, or video poker amusement machines, or any combination thereof, shall not be used, or allowed to be used, by the operator as gambling devices or for gambling purposes, or both. This chapter shall not be construed in any fashion to authorize, license, or permit gambling or any gambling devices, or both, within the corporate limits of the city (except as authorized by state law). Any amusement machine, music amusement machine, amusement ride, billiard table, or video poker amusement machine, or any combination thereof, that is used, or permitted to be used, by the operator for gambling purposes or as a gambling device, or both, shall be subject to confiscation by any proper law enforcement officer and agency and shall be grounds for the immediate termination of the regulatory license to operate said machine (including billiard table). 
(Ord. No. 106, § 10, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-10. - Regulatory license a privilege. 
The operation of amusement machines, music amusement machines, amusement rides, billiard rooms, or video poker amusement machines, or any combination thereof, in the city is a privilege, and not a right, and the issuance of a regulatory license hereunder shall not create any property or right in the licensee except to conduct the licensed business during the period the license is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 11, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-11. - Regulations. 
(a)  No holder of a regulatory license authorizing the operation of amusement machines, music amusement machines, amusement rides, billiard rooms, or video poker amusement machines, or any combination thereof, within the corporate limits of the city, nor any agent or employee of the licensee, shall do any of the following upon the licensed premises: 
(1)  When otherwise authorized under chapter 8, Alcoholic Beverages, as to the sale of alcoholic beverages, knowingly sell, serve, or permit the use of alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises unless the licensee derives at least 75 percent of its revenue from the sale of products or services other than alcoholic beverages. This subsection shall control over any provision of chapter 8. This provision shall not apply where the licensee operates three or fewer amusement machines or music amusement machines, or any combination thereof, on the premises, but the licensee must meet the revenue requirements under chapter 8 for sale by the drink for consumption on the premises in the city. All other terms and conditions of chapter 8 shall apply as to any premises which sells alcoholic beverages. 
(2)  Operate said machines (including billiard tables) in a building where the inside retail area of the building cannot be seen from outside the building due to a lack of windows, opaque windows, closed shutters, or painted-over windows. The inside retail area of the building must be visible from the outside. 
(3)  Knowingly permit or cause to be permitted by any person in the licensee's employ a minor to be upon the premises during days and hours of operation of any public school system within the city. 
(4)  Knowingly permit the operation of said machines (including billiard tables) during the hours beginning 12:00 midnight until 6:00 a.m. This prohibition of operating during said hours shall not apply where the licensee only operates one amusement machine. 
(5)  No licensee shall allow any person less than 12 years of age to be on, frequent, or loiter on the premises unless such minor is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. 
(6)  Operate said machines (including billiard tables) in a building that does not meet the building code of the city for buildings used by the public, and said premises must have properly marked exits and proper restroom facilities. 
(7)  Permit any disturbance of the peace or obscenity or any illegal, lewd, immoral, or improper entertainment, conduct, or practice on the licensed premises. Such illegal behavior or misconduct shall be immediately reported by the licensee to the proper law enforcement authorities. 
(8)  Permit said machines (including billiard tables) to be used for gambling purposes or as gambling devices, or both. 
(9)  Permit the operation of said machines, including music amusement machines, in such a manner, or with a volume, or both, so as to disturb the public peace and in such a manner as to constitute a public nuisance. Said machines shall not be operated or at a volume, or both, which can be heard from the nearest residence to the premises after 9:00 p.m. 
(10)  Permit any person to operate said machines on the premises without proper clothing (being proper dress of shirt, blouse, pants, shorts, skirt, and shoes, as applicable). 
(11)  No person shall allow or require a person in his employment under 18 years of age to sell or dispense coins, bills, other money, tokens, plates, discs, slugs, tickets, or other similar objects to operate said machines or to perform employment duties as to or concerning said machines. No holder of a regulatory license shall employ a person under 18 years of age. If the licensee sells alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises, any person in the employment of said licensee on the premises must be at least 21 years of age. 
(b)  The following shall be grounds for the suspension or revocation, or both, of said regulatory license. Whether or not said grounds exist shall be determined by the city council in its sole discretion: 
(1)  The violation by the license holder or his employee of any state or federal law or any ordinance of the city, other than traffic violations. The determination of whether any such violation has occurred shall be made by the city council, and an actual conviction in a court for such offense shall not be necessary in order to suspend or revoke the license. 
(2)  The failure of the license holder or his employee to report promptly to the proper law enforcement authorities any violation of law or municipal ordinance, breach of the peace, disturbance or altercation resulting in violence occurring on the premises. 
(3)  Any conduct on the part of the license holder or his employee contrary to the public welfare, safety, health or morals. 
(4)  Operating or conducting the business in a manner contrary to the public welfare, safety, health or morals or in such a manner as to constitute a public nuisance. 
(5)  The violation of any state law or regulation or municipal ordinance pertaining to alcoholic beverages, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 13, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-12. - Violations; reporting and acting on. 
(a)  Any violation of this chapter that may warrant revocation of the regulatory license shall be reported by any person to the mayor, who shall have the power, in his discretion, to suspend the license or permit for a period not to exceed ten days pending a hearing before the city council on the question of whether or not the license or permit shall be revoked for cause, in compliance with section 11-5(d). 
(b)  Upon a charge that there has been a violation of this chapter, the mayor is hereby authorized in his discretion to order the place of business charged closed, pending a hearing on the charge. 
(c)  Any proper law enforcement authority including, but not limited to, any city police department, the county sheriff's department, and the state bureau of investigation shall have the authority to close any location holding a regulatory license for a period not in excess of 24 hours in the event there shall occur on the premises any violation of law or municipal ordinance, breach of the peace, disturbance or altercation resulting in violence, or other occurrence which is contrary to the public health, safety, welfare or morals, when in the judgment of a proper agent for said law enforcement authorities that such action is necessary to protect the public health, welfare, safety or morals. 
(d)  The city council shall have the right to suspend any regulatory license pending the hearing provided for in section 11-5(d), where, in the judgment of the city council, such action is necessary to protect the public health, safety, welfare and morals. 
(e)  Any suspension as provided for in subsection (d) of this section shall be in writing with the reasons therefor stated and shall be delivered to the license holder or the person in charge of the place of business, if the license holder cannot be located. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 14, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-13. - General provisions. 
(a)  Where applicable, when the holder of the regulatory license sells, serves, or permits the use of alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises, and the 75 percent revenue requirement as provided by section 11-11(a)(1) is required, the 75 percent revenue requirement shall be determined on a calendar basis by a monthly report submitted by each licensee permitting such sales of alcoholic beverages. In the event that the 75 percent revenue requirement required by section 11-11(a)(1) falls below 75 percent of the business volume of alcoholic beverage sales for any quarter, the license holder shall be placed on probation for the next succeeding quarter. At the end of the next succeeding quarter, if the license holder's revenue from the sale of products or services, other than alcoholic beverages, has not obtained the 75 percent requirement, the mayor shall suspend said license in accordance with section 11-12(a). At the hearing before the city council in accordance with section 11-5(d), the city council, in its discretion, may revoke the regulatory license for noncompliance with the 75 percent revenue requirement of section 11-11(a)(1). Nothing herein provided shall prohibit the city council or the mayor from suspending or revoking said license for any other violations of this chapter. Authorized officials or agents, or both, of the city may examine the records of the licensee at any reasonable time to ascertain that the requirements of this and other provisions of this chapter are met. 
(b)  All of said machines shall be operated only on the premises for which the regulatory license is issued. 
(c)  The holder of every regulatory license hereunder shall have available in his place of business at all times a copy of this chapter and shall be responsible for compliance herewith by persons on the premises. 
(d)  Premises operated under the provisions of this chapter shall be open to inspection by authorized personnel of the city at all times. 
(e)  Upon receipt by the city clerk or any other properly designated agent of the city council of any application for a regulatory license (except as to those licenses as to which an applicant may submit a short-form application) or for the transfer of any license (except as to those licenses as to which an applicant may submit a short-form application), the clerk or proper agent of the city council shall forward the same to any proper law enforcement authority for investigation, who, following such investigation, shall attach thereto the entire police record of every person named in said application. The city clerk or other proper agent of the city council shall then submit the application with said report attached to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 15, 11-7-1994) 
Sec. 11-14. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall do anything prohibited by this chapter as the same exists, or as may hereafter be amended, or who shall do anything required by this chapter as the same exists, or as may hereafter be amended, besides having the regulatory license subject to suspension or revocation, shall be subject to the general penalties as described in section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 16, 11-7-1994) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3); dogs generally, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; rabies control and licensing of animals by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned animal. Any domesticated animal shall be considered "abandoned," for the purposes of this chapter, which shall have been placed upon public property or within a public building, unattended or uncared for, or upon or within the private property of another without the express permission of the owner, custodian or attendant of the private property and is unattended or uncared for. Any domesticated animal shall also be considered as abandoned, for the purposes of this chapter, which shall have been upon or within the property of the owner or custodian of this animal for a period of time in excess of 36 hours unattended and without proper food and water. 
Animal at large means an animal not under restraint. 
Animal control officer means any officer, agent or employee of the governing authority designated by the governing authority to perform the duties of animal control and enforcement of this chapter and to perform the duties of dog control officer pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22(c), as amended from time to time. 
Animal shelter. The term "animal shelter" means: 
(1)  Any facility operated by or under contract for the state, county, a municipal corporation, a political subdivision of the state or the county humane society for the purpose of impounding or harboring seized, stray, homeless, abandoned, or unwanted dogs, cats, and other animals; 
(2)  Any veterinary hospital or clinic operated by a veterinarian or veterinarians which operates for such purpose in addition to its customary purposes; and 
(3)  Any facility operated, owned, or maintained by a duly incorporated humane society, animal welfare society, or other nonprofit organization for the purpose of providing for and promoting the welfare, protection, and humane treatment of animals. 
Animal under restraint. Any domesticated animal is considered under restraint if: 
(1)  It is controlled within the property limits of its owner by a visible physical barrier (fence (nonelectronic), chain, leash, etc.) of its owner; 
(2)  It is controlled by a leash; 
(3)  It is at heel or beside a competent person and is obedient to the person's commands; or 
(4)  It is within the occupant enclosure of a vehicle or restrained if within the cargo area of a truck being driven or parked on the streets. 
Board of health means the county board of health. 
Dangerous animal means any animal that, according to the records of an appropriate authority: 
(1)  Has without provocation inflicted severe injury on a human being on public or private property; or 
(2)  Aggressively bites, attacks, or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the animal has been classified as a potentially dangerous animal and after the owner has been notified of such classification. 
Domesticated animal means an animal that is living in or about the habitation of people including, but not limited to, cats, chickens, dogs, ducks, cows, fowl, geese, horses, rabbits, swine, domesticated wild animals and/or exotic animals. Pen-raised skunks are categorized as those skunks acceptable by the state and may be kept in the state as pets. 
Exotic animal means any animal not native to the county and includes, but is not limited to, emus, iguanas, pythons, ostriches, reptiles and rhea. It shall also include any hybrid animal which is part exotic animal. 
Governing authority means the city council. 
Guard animal means any animal which has been trained to attack persons or other animals independently or upon oral command and any animal which, while not so trained, is reasonably expected to perform as a guardian of the property upon and within which it is located. 
Humane society means the county humane society or any corporation, organization or association existing for the purpose of prevention of cruelty to animals, education for humane treatment of animals or animal adoption for stray animals. 
Law enforcement agency means the city police department, the county sheriff's office or the county enforcement division. 
Livestock means any hoofed animal including, but not limited to, a cow, horse, goat, llama, bovine, equine and swine as well as all other animals used or suitable for either food or labor. 
Owner means any natural person or any legal entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm, or trust, who or which owns, possesses, harbors, keeps, cares for, feeds, maintains, has custody or control of, or knowingly permits to be harbored or kept or to remain on or about their premises an animal within the jurisdiction of the city council. 
Potentially dangerous animal means any animal with a known propensity, tendency, or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury, or to otherwise threaten the safety of human beings, or any animal that, when unprovoked: 
(1)  Inflicts injury on a human being on public or private property; or 
(2)  Chases or approaches a human being upon the street, sidewalks or any public grounds in a vicious or terrorizing manner in an apparent attitude of attack. 
Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous animal or potentially dangerous animal while on the owner's property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence, or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the animal from escaping. Any such structure shall have a secure top, and, if the animal is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed in such a manner as to prevent the animal's escape from the fence. If the enclosure does not have a floor, the sides of the enclosure shall be embedded in the ground not less than two feet. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the animal. 
Public or private animal refuge means harborers of unwanted animals of any breed, including crossbreeds, who provide food, shelter, and confinement for a group of dogs, a group of cats, or a combination of dogs and cats. 
Records of appropriate authority. The term "records of appropriate authority" means: 
(1)  Records of any state, county or municipal law enforcement agency; 
(2)  Records of any county or municipal animal control agency; 
(3)  Records of any county board of health; 
(4)  Records of any federal, state, or local court; 
(5)  Records of a dog control officer as provided in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22; or 
(6)  Records of an animal control officer as provided by this chapter. 
Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery, or a physical injury that results in death. 
Sexually mature animal means any dog or cat that has reached the age of 180 days or six months or more. 
Sterilization means the surgical removal of the reproductive organs of a dog or cat in order to render the animal unable to reproduce. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.010), 4-18-2002; Ord. of 9-24-2002, § 2) 
Sec. 14-2. - Animal control unit. 
There is created for the governing authority an animal control unit, totally separate from and independent of the county humane society, and it shall be staffed with such personnel as may from time to time be authorized by the governing authority. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.020), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-3. - Animal control officer; position established. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22(c), the duties of the dog control officer shall be vested in the director of the animal control unit. The title of the officer shall be animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.030), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-4. - Cooperation with animal control officer. 
(a)  An animal control officer is authorized to make whatever inquiry is deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. All law enforcement agencies of the governing authority shall cooperate with the animal control officers in enforcing the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful: 
(1)  To interfere with or fail to cooperate with any animal control officer or other officer acting pursuant to this chapter; 
(2)  To take or attempt to take any animal from a county vehicle used to transport an animal pursuant to this chapter; or 
(3)  To take or attempt to take any animal from the animal control shelter or other impounding area used by the county animal control for the purposes of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.040), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-5. - Enforcement of chapter. 
The primary responsibility for enforcement of this chapter shall be vested in the animal control unit, which may call upon such other officers and employees of any law enforcement agency of the governing jurisdiction as may be necessary for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.050), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-6. - Summons. 
Upon information known to, or a complaint lodged with, any officer or member of the animal control unit or any law enforcement agency employee of the governing authority, that any owner or possessor of an animal is in violation of this chapter, a summons shall be issued requiring the owner or possessor of such animal to appear before the judge of the magistrate court of the county on a day and time certain to stand trial for the violation. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.060), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-7. - Violations; penalty. 
Any person who shall do anything prohibited by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, or who shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the magistrate court of the county, and, upon conviction, shall be subject to both fine and imprisonment, as provided in O.C.G.A. §§ 36-32-1(c) and 36-35-6(a)2. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.070), 4-18-2002; Ord. of 9-24-2002, § 1) 
Sec. 14-8. - City may contract for animal control services. 
In the event that the city enters into a governmental agreement with another governing authority to provide animal control services, then the primary responsibility for enforcement of this chapter shall be vested in the animal control unit of that governing authority and the individual so designated by that governmental agreement. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.075), 4-18-2002) 
Secs. 14-9—14-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DUTIES TOWARDS ANIMALS 

Sec. 14-35. - Owner to keep animals under control. 
It is unlawful for the owner of any domesticated animal, or anyone having a domesticated animal in his possession or control, to permit such domesticated animal to be at large and not under restraint. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.080), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-36. - Rabies vaccination; fee. 
(a)  When any dog, cat or other animal as may be required by state law to be vaccinated for rabies is being kept in the jurisdiction of the governing authority, it shall be the duty of any owner or possessor or custodian of said animal to procure current rabies vaccination if said animal is three months of age or older, as required by and in accordance with the rabies control rules of the board of health. The owner, possessor or custodian shall affix to the collar or harness of the animal a current vaccination tag as prescribed by the board of health. 
(b)  The veterinarian administering the antirabies vaccine required by this section shall collect, in addition to the charges for vaccination, the sum of $0.50 for each dog vaccinated. The fees collected under this provision shall be delivered to the county board of commissioners by the veterinarian collecting said fees on or before the 20th day of the month following the month in which said fees were collected. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.090), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-37. - Display of rabies tag. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner of a dog, cat or other animal required to have a rabies vaccination by state law to allow such animal in any area of the jurisdiction of the governing authority without a visible collar which shall have attached a valid and current rabies vaccination tag as required by the board of health. It shall be the duty of each animal owner to provide a collar with a rabies vaccination tag for each animal, except when such animal is participating in an animal show or exhibition. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.100), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-38. - Loud noises prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any domesticated animal or bird that makes, continues or causes to be made or continued any loud, unnecessary or unusual sound or noise which unreasonably annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others in the jurisdiction of the governing authority and which is audible to a person of normal hearing ability more than 100 feet from the point of origin of this sound or noise. 
(b)  Anyone who keeps or maintains an animal or bird that unreasonably disturbs the comfort or repose of any person because the animal or bird is emitting frequent or long continued sound or noise, and who continues to keep, maintain, or allow any animal or bird to so disturb the comfort or repose of any person shall be deemed in violation of this section. 
(c)  This section shall apply to horses, livestock, poultry and other farm animals, provided they are maintained in accordance with the governing authority's zoning regulations or ordinances, with the following exception: Multiple roosters being raised on other than a bona fide farm are subject to this section. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.110), 4-18-2002; Ord. No. 407, exh. A(4.10.110), 4-15-2009) 
Sec. 14-39. - Abandonment. 
It is unlawful for the owner of any domesticated animal to knowingly abandon the animal within the jurisdiction of the governing authority. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.120), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-40. - Guard animals. 
(a)  In addition to all other requirements of this chapter, any person maintaining a guard animal in an area for the protection of persons or property shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The animal shall be confined to an enclosed area adequate to ensure that it will not escape. 
(2)  When not securely enclosed, the animal shall be under the absolute control of a handler at all times, muzzled and restrained by a secure leash which is not in excess of six feet in length and which is of sufficient strength to prevent escape. 
(3)  The owner or other persons in control of the premises upon which a guard animal is maintained shall post warning signs over or next to all exterior doors stating that such an animal is on the premises. At least one such sign shall be posted at each driveway or entranceway to said premises. Such sign shall be in lettering clearly visible from either the curbline or at a distance of 50 feet, whichever is greater, and shall contain a telephone number where some person responsible for controlling such guard animal can be reached 24 hours a day. 
(4)  The owner or custodian shall report to the animal control unit within 24 hours any of the following: 
a.  Escape of the animal; 
b.  An attack on a human or animal by the animal; 
c.  Transfer of ownership of the animal; or 
d.  Death of the animal. 
(b)  Prior to the placing of a guard animal on any property, the person responsible for the placing shall inform the animal control officer, all law enforcement agencies of the governing authority and the fire chief, in writing, of the following: 
(1)  Their intention to post said animal; 
(2)  The number of animals to be posted; 
(3)  The location where said animal will be posted; 
(4)  The approximate length of time said animal will be guarding the area; and 
(5)  The breed, sex, age and rabies tag number of said animal. 
Said notice must be renewed every 12 months. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.130), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-41. - Confining dogs and cats in heat. 
Every female dog or cat in heat shall be confined in a building or other enclosure in such manner that such female animal cannot come into contact with another sexually intact animal of the same species except for planned breeding. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.140), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-42. - Physical harm. 
Any person who causes undue suffering, deprives an injured or sick animal of necessary medical attention, tortures, torments, disfigures, maims, mutilates, kills, beats, bruises, wounds or poisons or exposes any poisonous substance with the intent that the poisonous substance should physically harm any domesticated animal, whether belonging to himself or another, shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.150), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-43. - Food, exercise and air. 
Any person who confines any animal, reptile or fowl and fails to supply it with sufficient quantities of wholesome food and water, or who keeps any animal, reptile or fowl in an enclosure without wholesome exercise and change of air shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.160), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-44. - Shelter. 
Any owner, custodian or possessor of any animal, reptile or fowl kept outdoors who fails, to provide shelter with at least a roof, a floor and three sides of adequate size for the animal, reptile or fowl it is intended for and sufficient to protect said animal, reptile or fowl from the elements shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.170), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-45. - Sanitation. 
Any owner, custodian or possessor of any domesticated animal who fails to maintain in a clean and sanitary condition and free from extreme and unreasonable objectionable odor all structures, pens, yards, and areas adjacent thereto wherein any animal is kept shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.180), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-46. - Leaving in autos. 
Any person who transports any animal, reptile or fowl in the trunk of any vehicle or leaves an animal or fowl in a vehicle in extreme heat without proper ventilation shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.190), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-47. - Fighting. 
No person shall: 
(1)  Own, possess, keep or train any animal or fowl with the intent that such animal or fowl shall be engaged in an exhibition of fighting; 
(2)  Build, make, maintain, or keep a pit on premises owned by him or occupied by him or allow a pit to be built, made, maintained or kept on such premises for the purposes of an exhibition of animal or fowl fighting; 
(3)  In any manner encourage, instigate, promote or assist in an exhibition of animal or fowl fighting or intentional combat; or 
(4)  Charge admission, be an assistant, umpire or participant or be present as a spectator to any exhibition or animal or fowl fighting or combat. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.200), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-48. - Use of animals as prizes. 
Any person who offers as a prize or gives away any animal, reptile or fowl in any contest, raffle or lottery or as an enticement for fundraising or for entry into any place of business shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.210), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-49. - Dying or coloring certain animals or fowl for display, sale, gift, etc., prohibited. 
No person shall sell, offer for sale, give away, or display living baby chicks, ducklings, or other fowl, or rabbits which have been dyed, colored or otherwise treated so as to impart to them an artificial color. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.220), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-50. - Procuring another to do act. 
Any person who procures another person to do any of the acts prohibited in sections 14-42 through 14-49 shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided for violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.230), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-51. - Exemptions. 
A person who is: 
(1)  Lawfully engaged in any sporting or hunting activity; 
(2)  Slaughtering animals, reptiles or fowl for the purpose of providing food; 
(3)  Engaged in the lawful euthanasia of an animal, reptile or fowl; or 
(4)  Acting as a law enforcement officer or animal control officer in the line of duty to protect against a case of aggression of an animal, reptile or fowl; 
shall not be charged with a violation of this article if the death of an animal, reptile or fowl occurs from any such lawful activity. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.240), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-52. - Disposal of dead animals. 
If a domesticated animal shall die, the owner must bury the carcass at least three feet below the ground level and have not less than three feet of earth over the carcass within 12 hours after the death and discovery of the carcass. In the event the public works director or his designee of the governing authority shall be designated by said governing authority to remove said carcasses, then it is unlawful to bury said carcass and said carcass shall be removed at the expense of the owner of the animal, if known, and the finance director of the governing authority shall collect the fee for the same as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.250), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-53. - Sterilization of animals. 
(a)  Any public or private animal shelter, animal control agency operated by a political subdivision of the state, humane society, or public or private animal refuge shall make provisions for the sterilization of all dogs or cats acquired from such shelter, agency, society, or refuge by: 
(1)  Providing sterilization by a licensed veterinarian before relinquishing custody of the animal; or 
(2)  Entering into a written agreement with the person acquiring such animal guaranteeing that sterilization will be performed by a licensed veterinarian within 30 days after acquisition of such animal in the case of a sexually mature animal or by the sexual maturity of the animal in the case of a sexually immature animal; 
provided, however, that the requirements of this section shall not apply to any privately owned animal which any such shelter, agency, society, or refuge may have in its possession for any reason if the owner of such animal claims or presents evidence that such animal is the property of such person. 
(b)  All costs of sterilization pursuant to this section shall be the responsibility of the person acquiring such animal and, if performed prior to acquisition, may be included in any fees charged by the shelter, agency, society, or refuge for such animal. 
(c)  Any person acquiring an animal from a public or private animal shelter, animal control agency operated by a political subdivision of the state, humane society, or public or private animal refuge, which animal is not sterile at the time of acquisition, shall submit to the animal shelter, animal control agency, humane society, or public or private animal refuge a signed statement from the licensed veterinarian performing the sterilization required by subsection (a)(2) of this section within seven days after such sterilization, attesting that such sterilization has been performed. 
(d)  Every public or private animal shelter, animal control agency operated by a political subdivision of the state, humane society, or public or private animal refuge selling or offering for sale or exchange any dog or cat shall maintain and furnish to any person acquiring an animal from such shelter, agency, society, or refuge a current list of veterinarians licensed in the state who have notified the shelter, agency, society, or refuge that they are willing to perform sterilizations and the cost for such procedures. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.260), 4-18-2002) 
Secs. 14-54—14-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 14-80. - Reasons. 
(a)  Any animal, reptile or fowl may be impounded if: 
(1)  It is not under restraint or is at large; 
(2)  It does not have a visible collar with a valid and current rabies vaccination tag affixed as required by section 14-37; 
(3)  It has been abandoned for 36 hours or more; 
(4)  It has bitten or is reasonably suspected of biting another animal or human and is being held for the required quarantine period under the rules of the board of health; or 
(5)  It has been abused as prohibited in sections 14-42 through 14-51. 
(b)  Said animal, reptile or fowl shall be impounded according to such rules and regulations now or hereafter prescribed by law or by the resolutions and ordinances of the governing authority for the detention, control and disposition of animals, reptiles and fowl. All impounded animals, reptiles and fowl, except exotic animals and livestock, shall be housed and cared for at the county humane society facilities. Impounded exotic animals and livestock will be housed at a facility approved by the governing authority. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.270), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-81. - Housing and care of dangerous or potentially dangerous animals. 
(a)  Upon a finding that an animal, reptile or fowl is dangerous or potentially dangerous and that the owner knew the animal, reptile or fowl was dangerous or potentially dangerous or upon confiscation pursuant to section 14-128, the animal, reptile or fowl may be impounded by the animal control unit or any law enforcement agency employee of the governing authority until such time as the owner of the dangerous or potentially dangerous animal provides proof of compliance with the duties of the owner of dangerous or potentially dangerous animals as set forth in article IV of this chapter. Any owner shall be held to know that such animal, reptile or fowl was dangerous or potentially dangerous if the animal, reptile or fowl had at any time displayed any one or more of the behaviors described in the definitions of dangerous or potentially dangerous animals in section 14-1. 
(b)  All animals, reptiles or fowl impounded under this section shall be housed and cared for at the county humane society facilities unless another facility which meets the requirements for housing a dangerous or potentially dangerous animal is expressly agreed upon between the animal control officer and the animal's owner. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.280), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-82. - Notice to owner; fees; redemption. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the animal control unit to immediately notify the owner of each domesticated animal impounded if the owner of the domesticated animal is known or can be reasonably ascertained. The owner of any domesticated animal impounded may reclaim such domesticated animal by the payment of: 
(1)  Any impoundment fee charged by the county; 
(2)  Any charges assessed by the county humane society for processing and boarding the animal; 
(3)  The cost of the rabies inoculation, if required due to the animal not wearing a current rabies inoculation tag; and 
(4)  Upon proof of payment of any fine already imposed for a violation of this chapter, within 72 hours of the impoundment of the animal, and, if after 72 hours, the animal has not been adopted through the county hall county. 
(b)  Owners of animals who have been identified and notified but who refuse to reclaim their animals will be responsible for said fees as charged by the county and the county humane society. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.290), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-83. - Disposition of animals. 
The animal control unit shall release to the county humane society for adoption or euthanasia any animal unredeemed or unclaimed by the owner after 72 hours, except as otherwise provided in this article. Any person adopting an animal from the county humane society that has been impounded by animal control shall pay any charges assessed by the humane society for required inoculations, as well as processing and boarding the animal, and show proof of payment of any fine already imposed for a violation of this chapter prior to receiving the animal. In the case of a dangerous or potentially dangerous animal, the person adopting the animal shall show proof of compliance with the duties of owners of dangerous or potentially dangerous animals before receiving the animal. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.300), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-84. - Destruction of biting animals. 
All animals or fowl, other than a dog or cat, which are known to have bitten a person or any animal which cannot be held for a rabies observation period shall be euthanized and a lab specimen of brain tissue sent to the state department of epidemiology for testing and control of rabies in accordance with the rules of the board of health. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.310), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-85. - Destruction of suffering animals. 
While being impounded, any animal, reptile or fowl which is suffering excessively or any animal which represents a real danger to persons or other animals, without regard to the period of confinement as provided in section 14-83, shall be destroyed by an animal control officer in as humane a manner as possible. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.320), 4-18-2002) 
Secs. 14-86—14-113. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DANGEROUS AND POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS ANIMALS 

Sec. 14-114. - Animal control officer; duties generally. 
The animal control officer shall make such investigations and inquiries as may be necessary to identify dangerous animals and dangerous animal owners within the jurisdiction of the governing authority. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.330), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-115. - Notice required. 
When a dangerous animal or potentially dangerous animal is classified as such, or when a potentially dangerous animal is reclassified as a dangerous animal, the animal control officer shall notify the animal's owner of such classification. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.340), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-116. - Contents of notice. 
Notices to the owner shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The notice shall be in writing and either mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address or hand-delivered to the owner. Such notice shall be complete either upon its mailing or, if hand-delivered, upon personal receipt. 
(2)  The notice shall include a summary of the animal control officer's findings that formed the basis for the animal's classification or reclassification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous animal. 
(3)  The notice shall be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the animal control officer's determination that the animal is a dangerous or potentially dangerous animal. 
(4)  The notice shall state that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the governing authority or its designee, and shall specify the name of the agency which shall conduct the hearing. 
(5)  The notice shall state that either a filing fee in the amount of $250.00 or a sufficient pauper's affidavit showing that the owner is unable without undue financial hardship to pay the filing fee shall be filed with the hearing request to the governing authority or its designee for said hearing. 
(6)  The notice shall state that, if a hearing is not requested, the animal control officer's determination that an animal is a dangerous or potentially dangerous animal will become effective for all purposes under this article on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing. 
(7)  The notice shall include a form to request a hearing before the governing authority or its designee and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the governing authority or its designee. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.350), 4-18-2002; Ord. No. 407, exh. A(4.10.350), 4-15-2009) 
Sec. 14-117. - Liability of owner. 
The notice procedures provided for in this article are not an essential condition for the enforcement of the provisions of this article. The owner of a dangerous or potentially dangerous animal is held to know that such animal is dangerous or potentially dangerous if the animal has, at any time, displayed any one or more of the behaviors described in the definitions of dangerous animals or potentially dangerous animals as provided in section 14-1. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.360), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-118. - Presiding body at hearings. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-22 and 4-8-24, the governing authority may conduct hearings provided for in this article, may designate an animal control board to conduct such hearings, or may designate the board of health to conduct such hearings. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.370), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-119. - Procedure for hearings. 
When the governing authority or its designee receives a request for a hearing as provided in section 14-116, along with payment of the fee or a sufficient pauper's affidavit showing that the owner is unable without undue financial hardship to pay the filing fee required for said hearing, it shall schedule such hearing within 30 days after receiving the request. The governing authority or its designee shall notify the animal owner in writing by certified mail of the date, time, and place of the hearing, and such notice shall be mailed to the animal owner at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the animal shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence, and in addition thereto the governing authority or its designee shall receive such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the governing authority or its designee may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify, or overrule the animal control officer's classification of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.380), 4-18-2002; Ord. No. 407, exh. A(4.10.380), 4-15-2009) 
Sec. 14-120. - Notice of determination. 
Within ten days after the date of the hearing, the governing authority or its designee shall notify the animal owner in writing by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the animal is a dangerous animal or a potentially dangerous animal, the notice shall specify the date upon which that determination is effective. If such determination is that the animal is not a dangerous animal or a potentially dangerous animal, then the governing authority or its designee for said hearing may, in its discretion, return to the animal owner any filing fee paid. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.390), 4-18-2002; Ord. No. 407, exh. A(4.10.390), 4-15-2009) 
Sec. 14-121. - Certificate of registration. 
It is unlawful for an owner to have or possess within the jurisdiction of the governing authority a dangerous animal or potentially dangerous animal without a certificate of registration issued annually in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.400), 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-122. - Proof of proper enclosure; posting of premises. 
Subject to the additional requirements of section 14-123, the animal control officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a dangerous or potentially dangerous animal if the owner presents to the animal control officer or the animal control officer otherwise finds sufficient evidence of: 
(1)  A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous animal or potentially dangerous animal; and 
(2)  The posting of the premises where the dangerous animal or potentially dangerous animal is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous animal on the property and containing a symbol designed to inform children of the presence of a dangerous animal. 
(Ord. No. 276, exh. A(4.10.410), 4-18-2002)
