Refuse means the useless, unused, unwanted, neglected, abandoned or discarded material resulting from normal household or commercial establishment activities, or materials which by their presence may injuriously affect the health, safety and welfare of persons in the city. 
Resource recovery and compactor sites means any resource recovery and compactor site operated by Hall County, Georgia. 
Solid waste means garbage, trash, refuse, rubbish, recyclables, yard waste, bulk items, and any other form of solid waste ordinarily resulting from normal household or commercial establishment activities. 
Yard waste means grass trimmings, leaves, small shrubbery trimmings, garden refuse, sod, pine needles, branches not in excess of six inches in diameter and four feet in length or 50 pounds in weight. Yard waste shall not include rock, dirt or roots. 
( Ord. No. 433, § I, 6-3-2010 ) 
Sec. 41-20. - Responsibility for management of solid waste, garbage, refuse and bulk items. 
(a)  Every person residing or conducting business in the city shall be responsible for ensuring that the solid waste, garbage, refuse and bulk items generated by their home or business is properly disposed of as set forth in this article. If any solid waste, garbage, refuse or bulk items can be identified as having last belonged to, been in the possession of, sent to or received by, or has been the property of any person or business prior to being disposed of, such identification shall be presumed to be prima facie evidence that such person or organization disposed of such solid waste in violation of this article. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to dispose of any solid waste, garbage, refuse or bulk items generated by their home except by the following approved methods: 
(1)  Utilize the city or a person(s) to whom the city may grant a franchise for collection, conveyance and disposal of said waste; 
(2)  Collect, convey and dispose of said waste at a county resource recovery and compactor site; or 
(3)  Collect, convey and dispose of said waste at any other state, county or city approved facility. 
(c)  The city shall report to the county the names and addresses of all persons who do not choose to use the city or its franchisee for the collection, conveyance and disposal of solid waste, garbage, refuse and bulk items or who do not have a plan approved by the director of community planning for collection, conveyance and disposal of solid waste, garbage, refuse and bulk items at a state, county (other than Hall County) or city approved facility. 
(d)  The city or its franchisee will collect garbage, refuse and bulk items in accordance with a schedule as established from time to time by the city and kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(e)  The city or its franchisee shall collect, convey and dispose of yard waste from property located within the city only upon request made to the city clerk, and hereby establishes a charge for said yard waste collection, conveyance and disposal. 
(f)  The following items, products, or materials will not be collected and it shall be a violation of this article for any person to place such items, products or materials in any container for collection: Paint, construction materials, rubber tires, acid, explosive material, inflammable liquids, hazardous substances, hazardous waste, biomedical waste and dangerous or corrosive material of any kind. 
( Ord. No. 433, § I, 6-3-2010 ) 
Sec. 41-21. - Collection days designated. 
Garbage and refuse shall be collected from the various premises in the city as follows: 
Collections from single family dwellings and commercial establishments will normally be made once weekly on Monday or Tuesday, except for legal holidays. One bulk item per month shall be collected once monthly on the second Monday or Tuesday, except for legal holidays. 
( Ord. No. 433, § I, 6-3-2010 ) 
Sec. 41-22. - Preparation and storage of garbage and refuse for collection. 
(a)  Garbage and refuse shall be placed in plastic bags with the tops securely tied and stored in the container(s) provided by the city or its franchisee. Garbage and refuse placed in containers un-bagged in plastic will not be collected and the customer will be notified of noncompliance with this section. 
(b)  Each occupied single family dwelling or commercial establishment shall be provided at least one container with a capacity of 96 gallons. One additional container may be provided at an additional cost to the sanitation service customer in an amount established by resolution of the city council or by its franchisee. Neither the city nor its franchisee will collect garbage and refuse from single family dwellings or commercial establishments which cannot be stored in a maximum of two such containers. 
(c)  The director of community planning shall not issue a building permit for multifamily dwellings until the said dwelling have an approved plan for the collection, storage and disposal of garbage and refuse. Neither the city nor its franchisee will collect garbage and refuse from multifamily dwellings unless the refuse is placed in containers approved by the city council or its franchisee. 
(d)  Containers shall be maintained in a sanitary condition, tightly covered at all times except for filling, emptying and cleaning, free from odor and such containers shall be filled in such manner as to allow pickup by one person. Such container shall be further maintained so as to prevent the overflow or scattering of garbage and refuse. 
(e)  Containers which are inside fenced areas will not be picked up. Garbage and refuse shall be ready for pickup no later than 6:00 a.m. on the designated pickup days. If the containers are placed curbside for garbage and refuse removal, they shall be removed from the curb the same day as the garbage and refuse is collected. 
(f)  Yard waste shall be placed in clear plastic bags or if opaque plastic bags or paper bags are used they must be marked as "yard waste." Said bags shall be placed immediately behind the sidewalk or if there is no sidewalk, immediately behind the curb or off the pavement and shall not be located as to impede or obstruct or divert either pedestrian or vehicular traffic or the flow of surface water or block drains. No garbage or refuse shall be mixed with yard waste. 
( Ord. No. 433, § I, 6-3-2010 ) 
Sec. 41-23. - Commercial establishments and large multifamily dwellings. 
(a)  All commercial establishments and large multifamily dwellings within the city unable to store its garbage and refuse as provided in subsection [(b)] shall arrange for proper garbage and refuse collection, conveyance, and disposal from a private contractor. 
(b)  All containers shall be maintained on private property except where permission is granted by the city council to utilize public alleys, streets or sidewalks. 
(c)  All commercial establishments shall maintain containers in a sanitary condition free from odor and shall prevent the overflow or scattering of garbage on the premises, nearby properties or public streets and places. 
(d)  The planning director or his designee shall not issue a building permit for commercial establishments or large multifamily dwellings until said premises have approved plans for the collection, storage and disposal of garbage and refuse. 
(e)  Provisions of this section shall not apply to persons who, as an incidental part of providing construction or demolition services, and using vehicles, dumpsters or roll-off containers which they own or lease, remove construction or demolition debris from the sites at which they are performing such services. This provision shall not be construed to relieve such persons of any requirements under federal or state law. 
( Ord. No. 433, § I, 6-3-2010 ) 
Sec. 41-24. - Billing procedure. 
(a)  All persons utilizing the city's franchisee(s) for collection, conveyance and disposal of solid waste, garbage, refuse and bulk items shall be billed directly by the franchisee(s). 
(b)  All persons utilizing the county resource recovery and collection sites for collection, conveyance and disposal of solid waste, garbage, refuse and bulk items shall be billed in accordance with the county's code of ordinances. 
( Ord. No. 433, § I, 6-3-2010 ) 
Sec. 41-25. - Placing of solid waste for pickup. 
(a)  All persons utilizing sanitation services of the city or its franchise shall place solid waste items for pick-up on their premises located so as to be easily accessible to street pickup, not to be placed over or next to fixed items such as fire hydrants, telephone or electrical boxes, mail boxes or anything that could be damaged by equipment or personnel picking up said items, but not including the street, sidewalk, or properties other than the premises of the depositor. Neither the city nor its franchisee will be responsible for repairing or replacing items removed or damaged which was placed curbside in such a manner that it appeared to be intended for removal or was not visible because it was mixed with other items placed curbside. 
(b)  Neither the city nor its franchisee shall be responsible for collecting or hauling construction or demolition waste. Such material must be disposed of by the contractor, tenant, or owner of the property. Neither the city nor its franchisee shall not be responsible for collecting or hauling trees, bushes, or other vegetation from commercial tree trimmers, landscapers, grading contractors or building contractors. 
(c)  For rental properties, all solid waste originating from the property during the clean up between tenants shall be the responsibility of the landlord and/or the property owner. The following shall apply to all solid waste originating from the property of a landlord cleaning up between tenants: 
(1)  Following an eviction, any property, solid waste, belongings, or other items shall be placed on some portion of the landlord's property, immediately behind the sidewalk or if there is no sidewalk, immediately behind the curb or off the pavement and shall not be located as to impede or obstruct or divert either pedestrian or vehicular traffic or the flow of surface water or block drains. 
(2)  After execution of a writ of possession, such property shall be regarded as abandoned. Any property, solid waste, belongings, or other items placed curbside following an eviction shall be removed within 24 hours of the physical eviction by the property owner. If the property is not removed with 24 hours, the city may commence removal at the expense of the property owner and the property owner shall be deemed in violation of this article. 
( Ord. No. 433, § I, 6-3-2010 ) 
Sec. 41-26. - Unauthorized use of dumpsters and prohibiting scavenging. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, deposit or otherwise leave solid waste in dumpsters that are leased and paid for private use, except by permission of the owner. This prohibition includes dumpsters on government property. Only dumpsters marked "For Public Use" shall be used and it shall be unlawful to import garbage to these dumpsters. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to scavenge or remove solid waste from dumpsters. Solid waste in these dumpsters is the property of the company providing the service. 
(c)  Each dumpster shall display one sign in easy to read printing, which sign shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Notice that the unauthorized and unlawful use of the dumpster is a violation of this section. 
(2)  Warning that violators will be prosecuted. 
( Ord. No. 433, § I, 6-3-2010 ) 
Sec. 41-27. - Penalties. 
Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this article shall on conviction thereof be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or imprisonment for six months or both such fine and imprisonment or may fix punishment by fine, imprisonment or alternative sentencing as now, or hereafter provided by law. Each day in violation of any provision of this article shall be considered a separate offense. 
( Ord. No. 433, § I, 6-3-2010 ) 
ARTICLE III. - RESERVED 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 433 , § I, adopted June 3, 2010 deleted Art. III, §§ 41-47—41-51, which pertained to yard trimmings and derived from Ord. No. 129, §§ 1—5, 1-6-1997. 
Chapter 42 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENT DISTRICTS 
ARTICLE I. - STREET LIGHTING DISTRICTS 

Sec. 42-1. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to create special districts for the provision of street lighting services along public rights-of-way within such districts and to levy and collect assessments within each district to pay the cost of providing such services. 
( Ord. No. 451, § 1, 9-1-2011 ) 
Sec. 42-2. - Standards. 
Existing and proposed public street lights shall comply with the following standards: 
(a)  Existing public streets—Above ground power. Street lights shall be installed on existing utility poles at a spacing no closer than 200 lineal feet with 100 watt minimum fixtures. 
(b)  Existing public streets—Underground power. Street lights shall be installed on poles and in conformance with all applicable standards of the city and utility provider. 
(c)  Proposed public streets. The owner, developer or other person developing a subdivision providing street light services shall be required to conform to all of the standards provided in Article 10 Section 1026 "Street Lights" of the city's adopted Subdivision and Land Development Ordinance. 
( Ord. No. 451, § 1, 9-1-2011 ) 
Sec. 42-3. - Districts other than residential. 
Street lighting in nonresidential districts shall only be permitted by city council approval subject to the safety, economic and other factors involved. Nonresidential lighting districts shall be established consistent with the procedures set forth in this article. 
( Ord. No. 451, § 1, 9-1-2011 ) 
Sec. 42-4. - Cost of service for creation. 
The city council does hereby declare that the cost of service for creation of street light districts or street lighting hereafter created shall be a "service" as authorized by the Constitution of the state. 
( Ord. No. 451, § 1, 9-1-2011 ) 
Sec. 42-5. - Responsibility for costs; fees and charges; security deposit. 
(a)  Each property owner receiving street lighting service within a street light district created by the city council shall be required to pay a special assessment levied on each property for the provision of such service in an amount established by resolution of the city council. This assessment shall be equal to each property owner's pro-rata share of the total charge for annual lighting within the district based on the charges of electric utility companies plus an annual fee to cover administrative costs. 
(b)  Alternatively, a property owners' association as defined by the Georgia Property Owners' Association Act, as may be amended, may petition the city council on forms provided by the city to pay the special assessment for an entire district provided that the property owners' association currently receives an ad valorem tax bill. The city council may elect to collect a security deposit from the property owners' association. Said security deposit shall be in an amount established by resolution of the city council. 
( Ord. No. 467, § 1, 8-2-2012 ) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 467 , § 1, adopted Aug. 2, 2012, repealed former § 42-5 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 451 , § 1, 9-1-2011. 
Sec. 42-6. - Tax lot or parcel defined costs for nonresidential lots. 
Tax lot or parcel is hereby defined as any single tract of land which falls within any of the zoning classifications as defined by the city's zoning ordinance, as shown on the city land lot maps, or as shown on the county tax maps. However, in nonresidental zoning areas different criteria may be adopted by the city council for the payment of installation and operational costs. 
( Ord. No. 451, § 1, 9-1-2011 ) 
Sec. 42-7. - Payment due date; penalties; imposition of liens; forfeiture of security deposit. 
Payment of the fees provided for in this article shall be due the same date of each year as ad valorem taxes are due to the city. Failure to pay shall subject the property owner or the property owners' association to the same penalties provided for failure to pay ad valorem taxes. The fees charged for street lighting services shall constitute a special assessment on each property served by such services. The fees charged for street lighting services shall be added to the property owner or the property owners' association's ad valorem tax bill and shall constitute a lien on the property owned. Said liens shall have the same priority as tax assessments, and an execution may issue for the purposes of enforcing the lien including foreclosure and or judicial sale. Additionally, a property owners' association's failure to pay the fees provided for in this article shall forfeiture its security deposit and may result in the discontinuance of lighting service within the special assessment district. In the event the property owners' association fails to pay the fees provided for in this article, the next annual lighting charge for the special assessment district shall be levied in accordance with section 42-5(a). 
( Ord. No. 467, § 1, 8-2-2012 ) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 467 , § 1, adopted Aug. 2, 2012, repealed former § 42-7 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 451 , § 1, 9-1-2011. 
Sec. 42-8. - Billing, accounting, collecting and receiving monies. 
The city clerk shall be responsible for the billing, accounting, collecting, and receiving of the monies provided for in this article. 
( Ord. No. 451, § 1, 9-1-2011 ) 
Sec. 42-9. - Creation of a street lighting special assessment district. 
(a)  By property owner. Any tax lot or parcel owner in the city may present a request for creation of a special taxing district for street lights to the city council. Upon receipt of the request, the city council shall determine the appropriate boundaries for a special assessment district for street lights that will serve the lot owner presenting the request and neighboring lot owners. The city council shall then prepare a map showing this proposed special assessment district for street lights. The requesting lot owner shall then circulate a petition for the creation of the proposed special assessment district for street lights among the lot owners in the proposed district. If 51 percent of the lot owners in the proposed district sign the petition affirming the creation of a special assessment district for new or existing street lights, then the petition shall be presented to the city council. The city clerk shall verify the signatures on the petition prior to advertising the public hearings required by this section. Following signature verification, the city council shall conduct two public hearings for the purpose of determining whether or not to create the proposed special assessment district for street lights. Safety and economic factors shall be the prime consideration in making such determination. The public hearings shall be advertised at least one time in the official organ of the county, giving notice of the hearings at least 15 days before the public hearings. Following the public hearings, the city council may approve, by ordinance, a street lighting district. Following adoption of said ordinance, the city council shall notify the city clerk to apply a special assessment for each property to pay as part of the city's annual ad valorem property tax bill. 
(b)  The city council on its own action may initiate a street lighting district for any area of the city for which the city is being charged or will be charged for electrical service by the electric utility company servicing the area encompassing the proposed street lighting district. The city council shall conduct two public hearings for the purpose of determining whether or not to create the proposed special taxing district for street lights. Safety and economic factors shall be the prime consideration in making such determination. The public hearings shall be advertised one time in the official organ of the county, giving notice of the hearings at least 15 days before the public hearings. Following the public hearings, the city council may approve, by ordinance, a street lighting district. Following adoption of said ordinance, the city council shall notify the city clerk to apply a special assessment for each property to pay as part of the city's annual ad valorem property tax bill. 
( Ord. No. 451, § 1, 9-1-2011 ) 
Chapter 44 - TAXATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 44-1—44-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FREEPORT EXEMPTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Voters approved the Freeport exemption in a referendum held March 15, 1994. 
State Law reference— Freeport exemption, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.2. 

Sec. 44-19. - Title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as the Constitutional Freeport Exemption Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 165, § 1, 12-21-1998) 
Sec. 44-20. - Effective within corporate limits of city. 
The general constitutional Freeport exemption law as set forth in article VII, section II, paragraph III of the Constitution of the State of Georgia of 1983 (Ga. Const. art. VII, § II, ¶ III) and O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.2 is hereby made effective within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 165, § 2, 12-21-1998) 
Sec. 44-21. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Finished goods means goods, wares and merchandise of every character and kind but shall not include unrecovered, extracted or unsevered natural resources, raw materials, goods in the process of manufacture or production or the stock in trade of a retailer. 
Raw materials means any material whether crude or processed that can be converted by manufacture, processing or combination into a new and useful product but shall not include unrecovered, unextracted or unsevered natural resources. 
(b)  All other definitions, terms and provisions of the aforesaid constitutional amendment and O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.2 shall be and the same are hereby incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference thereto. 
(Ord. No. 165, § 4, 12-21-1998) 
Sec. 44-22. - Ad valorem taxation exemptions. 
The city does exempt from ad valorem taxation all the value of the following types of tangible personal property or any combination thereof is and shall be exempted from ad valorem taxation: 
(1)  Inventory of goods in the process of manufacture or production, which shall include all partly finished goods and raw materials held for direct use or consumption in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business in the state. The exemption provided for herein shall apply only to tangible personal property which is substantially modified, altered or changed in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing, processing or production operations in the state. 
(2)  Inventory of finished goods manufactured or produced within the state in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business when held by the original manufacturer or producer of such finished goods. The exemption provided for herein shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is produced or manufactured. 
(3)  Inventory of finished goods which, on January 1, are stored in a warehouse, dock or wharf, whether public or private, and which are destined for shipment to a final destination outside the state, and inventory of finished goods which are shipped into the state from outside the state and stored transshipment to a final destination outside the state. The exemption provided for herein shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is stored in the state. All property that is claimed to be exempt under the provisions of this subsection shall be designated as being in transit upon the official books and records of the warehouse, dock, or wharf, whether public or private, where such property is being stored. Such official books and records shall contain a full, true and accurate inventory of all such property, including the date of the receipt of the property, the date of the withdrawal of the property, the point of origin of the property and the point of final destination of the same, if known. The official books and records of any such warehouse, dock, or wharf, whether public or private, pertaining to any such in transit property shall be at all times open to the inspection of all taxing authorities of the state and of any political subdivision of the state. 
(Ord. No. 165, § 3, 12-21-1998) 
Sec. 44-23. - Increase, reduction, revocation of exemption. 
Any increase, reduction or revocation of such exemption may be accomplished only by the procedures set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.2. 
(Ord. No. 165, § 5, 12-21-1998) 
Secs. 44-24—44-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL-MOTEL EXCISE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 379-A , §§ 1—17, adopted Apr. 1, 2010, did not specify manner of inclusion. Hence, to facilitate indexing, said provisions have been included herein as Art. III, §§ 44-31—4-47. 

Sec. 44-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City means the City of Flowery Branch, Georgia. 
Due date means the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed. 
Guest room means a room occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
Hotel means any structure or any portion of a structure, including any lodging house, rooming house, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, studio hotel, motel, motor hotel, auto court, truckstop, tourist cabin, lodge, inn, timeshare or other condominium, apartment community, public club, or private club, containing guest rooms and which is occupied, or is intended or designed for occupancy, by paying guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor, or otherwise. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to use or possession of any room or apartment in a hotel, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. 
Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license or use, or other agreement, or otherwise. 
Operator means any person operating a hotel in this city including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, the lessee, sublessee, lender in possession; licensee or any other person otherwise operating such hotel. 
Permanent resident means any occupant as of a given date who has or shall have occupied or has or shall have the right of occupancy of any guest room in a hotel for more than 30 consecutive days. 
Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number, excepting the United States of America, the state and any political subdivision of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax herein provided. 
Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money—whether received in money or otherwise—including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction there from whatsoever. 
Return means any return filed or required to be filed as herein provided. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 1, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-32. - Hotel-motel excise tax levy. 
There is hereby set and levied on each occupant of a guest room of any hotel located within the corporate limits of the city a tax in the amount of five percent of the rent for such occupancy. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 2, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-33. - Proceeds of the tax. 
The proceeds of this tax shall be used in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3). 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 3, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-34. - Use of funds generated by additional taxes. 
Upon approval by the city council of the city on an annual basis, the additional tax imposed by this article in excess of the first three percent shall be paid to the Lake Lanier Convention and Visitors Bureau ("Lake Lanier CVB") so long as (a) the majority of the funds paid are used for advertising and promoting the city and its surrounding area and (b) the city has representation on the Lake Lanier CVB. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 4, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-35. - Collection of tax by operator. 
It shall be the duty of every operator of a hotel located within the city to collect the tax on occupants imposed in section 44-32 of this article. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 5, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-36. - Exemptions. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this article: 
(a)  No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a permanent resident. 
(b)  No tax shall be imposed on charges made for hotel rooms, provided to any person who certifies that they are staying in such hotel room, as a result of the destruction of their home or residence by fire or other casualty. 
(c)  The tax authorized by this article shall apply to the fees or charges for any hotel room during the first 30 days of continuous occupancy and shall not apply to charges imposed for any continuous occupancy thereafter. The tax authorized by this article shall not apply to charges made for the use of meeting rooms and other such facilities or to any hotel room provided without charge. 
(d)  The tax authorized by this article shall not apply to the charges for any hotel room, furnished for a period of one or more days for use by state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business. Notwithstanding the availability of any other means of identifying the person as a state or local government official or employee, whenever a person pays for any hotel room with a state or local government credit card, such room shall be deemed to have been furnished for use by the state or local government official or employee traveling on official business for purposes of the exemption provided by this subsection. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 6, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-37. - Registration of operator. 
(a)  Every person engaging in or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in this city shall immediately register such business with the city clerk, on a form provided by the city clerk for such purpose. The required registration hereunder shall set forth the name under which the operator transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place or places of business, and such information as would facilitate the collection of the tax by the city clerk. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; by a member or partner in case of ownership by an association or partnership; by an officer in the case of ownership by a corporation. 
(b)  A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 7, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-38. - Certificate of taxing authority. 
Upon the registration of an operator under this article, the city clerk shall issue to such operator without charge a certificate of authority to collect the tax on occupants. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it relates. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 8, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-39. - Due date and required report. 
All taxes levied by this article shall be due and payable to the city clerk monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective month in which such taxes are collected, and payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the period, and such other information as may be required by the city clerk. The tax imposed by this article shall become delinquent for each month after the 20th day of each succeeding month during which it remains unpaid. An operator who fails to make any return or to pay the taxes levied by this article, shall be assessed a specific penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for one month or less; and an additional five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional month or fraction thereof in which such failure shall continue; provided, however, that the aggregate penalty for any single violation shall not exceed 25 percent or $25.00, whichever is greater. Delinquent amounts shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, until paid. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 9, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-40. - Collection fee allowed operators. 
Operators collecting the tax levied by this article shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from the state sales and use tax pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1, et seq. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 10, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-41. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  If any operator fails to file a return as required under the provisions of this article, the city clerk or his designated representative shall make an estimate of the amount of gross rentals of such operator which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in which the operator failed to file the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the city clerk. 
(b)  The city clerk or his designated representative shall give to the operator written notice of his determination as herein provided. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the city clerk. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. 
(c)  Penalties and interest shall be assessed upon the amount of any determination as provided in section 44-39 of this article. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 11, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-42. - Deficiency determination. 
(a)  If the city clerk or his designated representative is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any operator, he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. 
(b)  The city clerk or his designated representative shall give to the operator written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the city. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee, or when made by statutory overnight delivery. 
(c)  Penalties and interest shall be assessed upon the amount of any determination as provided in section 44-39 of this article. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 12, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-43. - Required records. 
Each operator collecting a tax under the provisions of this article shall keep, for a period of at least three years, all records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers setting forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the date or dates of occupancy, and such other information as the city clerk may require. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 13, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-44. - Administration and enforcement. 
The city clerk or his designated representative shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax herein imposed, and in so doing shall have the following powers: 
(a)  To examine, or authorize the examination of, the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator renting hotel rooms to persons subject to the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid; 
(b)  To require the filing of reports by any person having in his possession or custody information relating to rentals of hotel rooms which are subject to the tax herein levied. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 14, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-45. - Action for collection of tax. 
At any time within three years after any tax levied under this article or any portion of such tax required to be collected becomes due and payable, the city attorney may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect such amount due, together with interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 15, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-46. - Successors or assignees of operator. 
If any operator liable for any tax, interest, or penalty imposed by this article sells his or her business or quits the business, he or she shall make a final return and payment within 15 days after the date of selling or quitting the business. The operator's successors or assigns, if any, shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase money to cover the amount of the taxes, interest, and penalties due under this article and unpaid until the former owner and/or operator produces either a receipt from the city showing that the taxes, interest, and penalties due under this article have been paid or a certificate from the city that no tax, interest, or penalty is due under this article. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold the purchase money as required by this article, that person shall be personally liable for the payment of any taxes, interest, and penalties accruing under this article and unpaid by any former owner and/or operator and/or assignor. The personal liability of the purchaser in such a case shall not exceed the amount of the total purchase money, but the property being transferred shall in all cases be subject to the full amount of the tax lien arising from the delinquencies of the former owner and/or operator and/or assignor. Paid executions may be transferred and enforced as otherwise provided by law. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 16, 4-1-2010 ) 
Sec. 44-47. - Penalties. 
Any operator who shall violate any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor amenable to the process of the city's municipal court and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided by the city's charter and as otherwise allowed by law. Each and every day that a violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. 
( Ord. No. 379-A, § 17, 4-1-2010 ) 
Chapter 47 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference— Cities are authorized to exercise power over parking facilities and traffic control devices, Ga. Const. art. Chapter 50 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Home rule powers of municipality to regulate sewage collection and disposal systems and water treatment systems, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(6), (7); Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq.; municipalities authorized to acquire, construct, operate and maintain water and sewage systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Rates for water and sewer use. 
(a)  All water furnished by the city to users or property situated within or without the corporate limits shall be metered and computed monthly and be paid for at rates as established by resolution of the city council which shall be maintained on file with the city clerk. 
(b)  All sewer service furnished by the city to users or property situated within or without the corporate limits shall be metered and computed monthly and be paid for at rates as established by the city council which shall be maintained on file with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 2, 12-20-1993; Ord. No. 100-C, § 1, 5-23-2000; Ord. No. 100-D, § 1, 4-20-2004; Ord. No. 100-F, § 1, 12-15-2006) 
Sec. 50-2. - Application for water and/or sewer service. 
(a)  A person or entity seeking water service, sewer service or both from the city shall make application to the city. 
(b)  An applicant seeking water service, sewer service or both for residential use shall make a cash security deposit at the time of application for each service sought. A schedule of such cash security deposits as established by resolution of the city council shall be maintained on file with the city clerk. 
(c)  The amount of the cash security deposit for other than residential use shall be established by resolution of the city council, considering the following factors: 
(1)  The history of utility service with the application; 
(2)  The anticipated amount of service that the applicant will require; 
(3)  The typical monthly bill for an applicant; 
(4)  The type of sewage that would be discharged, if applicable; and 
(5)  Such other factors that would bear on the provision of water and sewer service. 
(d)  Every applicant shall pay an administrative start-up fee in an amount established by resolution of the city council at the time of applying for water service, sewer service or both to cover administrative bookkeeping, the administrative labor in beginning and ending service, and providing a final accounting to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 3, 12-20-1993; Ord. No. 100-B, § 1, 7-6-1998; Ord. No. 100-E, § 1, 10-4-2006) 
Sec. 50-3. - Water and sewer service connection. 
(a)  Each consumer subscribing to use the water service of the city shall pay a connection fee in an amount as established by resolution of the city council which shall be maintained on file with the city clerk. 
(b)  Each potential consumer who desires to use the sewer service of the city shall make application to the director of community planning on such forms and with such information as determined by the director of community planning. 
(c)  Applications for sewer service shall be approved as follows: 
(1)  Applications requesting an allocation of sewer capacity up to 5,000 gallons per day shall be approved by the city manager. 
(2)  Applications requesting an allocation of sewer capacity over 5,000 gallons per day shall be approved by the city council. 
(d)  Each applicant approved to use the sewer service of the city shall, within 60 days of approval, pay a connection fee for the total allocated sewer capacity in an amount as established by resolution of the city council which shall be maintained on file with the city clerk. 
(e)  The allocation of sewer capacity shall be reserved for a period of two years from the date of approval at no additional charge. However, if after two years from the date of approval the applicant, property owner or user is not using at least 20 percent of the allocated sewer capacity, the city shall notify the applicant, property owner or user of the insufficient use. Within 30 days from the receipt of said notice, the applicant, property owner or user shall pay a reservation extension fee in the amount of 20 percent of the total connection fee. The payment of a reservation extension fee shall entitle the applicant, property owner or user to a one time extension of the reservation of the allocated sewer capacity for one year from the date of payment of a reservation extension fee. If a reservation extension fee is not timely received by the city, the applicant, property owner or user shall forfeit any unused sewer capacity allocation and receive a refund equal to 80 percent of the connection fee for the forfeited sewer capacity. 
(f)  The applicant, property owner or user may at any time return any allocated sewer capacity to the city and receive a refund equal to 80 percent of the charge for the returned sewer capacity. 
(g)  If sewer capacity use on any day exceeds the sewer capacity purchased, the applicant, property owner or user shall pay the connection/capacity fee established by resolution of the city council for the excess used. 
(h)  Sewer capacity is allocated specifically to the property and may not be transferred or assigned to any other property or to any other person other than a subsequent owner of the property to which the sewer capacity was originally allocated. 
(i)  A subsequent owner of the property to which sewer use is measured by a water master meter shall not be required to pay a connection fee for the amount of sewer capacity originally allocated except that the subsequent owner shall pay to the city all reasonable costs, including, but not limited to, the cost of permitting, inspecting and making new connections, associated with any changes to sewer infrastructure and sewer metering attributable to the change in use in amounts established by resolution of the city council. 
(j)  The amount of sewer capacity originally allocated shall be confirmed by resolution of the city council. 
(k)  In the event the subsequent owner of the property to which sewer capacity was originally allocated changes the use of the property such that less capacity is required, the difference in capacity required reverts to the city at no cost to the city. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 4, 12-20-1993; Ord. No. 100-B, § 2, 7-6-1998; Ord. No. 100-C, § 2, 5-23-2000; Ord. No. 100-F, § 2, 12-15-2006; Ord. No. 100-G, § 1, 6-20-2007; Ord. No. 100-H, § 1, 12-5-2007) 
Sec. 50-4. - Change of occupancy. 
(a)  Not less than three days' notice must be given, in person or in writing, at the city hall to discontinue water and sewer service or to change occupancy. The outgoing party shall be responsible for all water consumed and the discharge of all sewage up to the time of departure or the time specified for departure, whichever period is longer. The new occupant shall apply for water service or sewer service, or both, within 48 hours after occupying the premises, and failure to do so will make him liable for paying for the water consumed and the sewage discharged since the last meter reading. 
(b)  In the event a user in good standing, as to the payment of all charges, assessments and taxes properly assessed by the city to said user, is merely relocating and is to continue to receive the same water service or sewer service, or both, from the city, then the user shall not be assessed the administrative start-up fee as provided by section 50-2(d), for the first relocation. Any subsequent relocation by said user shall bear the administrative start-up fee. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 5, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-5. - Meter reading; billings; collecting. 
(a)  Bills to customers for water and sewer service shall be mailed out on such days of each month as may be determined as desirable by the city. Bills shall be paid at the city hall and a failure to receive bills or notices shall not prevent such bills from becoming delinquent nor relieve the consumer from payment of same. The failure of water and/or sewer users to pay charges duly imposed shall result in the automatic imposition of the following penalties: 
(1)  All water/sewer bills are due by the 20th day of the month. A nonpayment penalty of ten percent of the total amount owed will be added to the delinquent account on the 21st day of the month. 
(2)  Nonpayment by the first of the month from the date due will result in the water being shut off from the water user's property. 
(3)  Nonpayment for 60 days after original due date will allow the city, in addition to all other rights and remedies, to terminate the agreement, and in such event, the water user shall not be entitled to receive, nor the city obligated to supply, any water under this agreement. 
(b)  Service scheduled for disconnection or which has been disconnected for nonpayment for service will be restored only after the past month bill(s) and current bill is paid in full and a service charge is paid. The service charge is hereby established in an amount to be set by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  Return check fee. A $25.00 or five percent of the face amount of the instrument, whichever is greater, service charge will be charged on all checks returned to the city for insufficient funds, account closed, etc. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 6, 12-20-1993; Ord. No. 100-B, § 3, 7-6-1998; Ord. No. 442, § 1, 9-23-2010 ; Ord. No. 510, § I, 5-7-2015 ) 
Sec. 50-6. - Suspension of service. 
(a)  When water and sewer service is discontinued and all bills paid, the security deposit shall be refunded to the consumer by the city. 
(b)  Upon discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills, the security deposit will be applied by the city toward settlement of the account. Any balance will be refunded to the consumer; however, if the security deposit is insufficient to cover the bill, the city may proceed to collect the balance in the usual way provided by law for collection of debts. 
(c)  The city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this section by the discontinuance of water service and sewer service in the event any person shall continue to violate the provisions of this section after receiving verbal or written notice of the violation from the city. 
(d)  Whenever the city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative determines that a person is violating or has violated any provision of this section and determines that the violation of this section will cause immediate damage or harm to the sewers, sewerage treatment process, equipment or treatment facilities of the city, or that the violation endangers the public health, safety or general welfare of the community, the city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative shall have the power and authority to immediately revoke, verbally or in writing, any sewerage permit of the person violating any provision of this section or terminate that person's water service and sewer service, or both. 
(e)  Any person aggrieved by having any sewerage permit or water and sewer service terminated, or both, revoked by the city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative, shall have the right to appeal the revocation to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken within five days from the date of the revocation by notifying the city clerk in writing and specifying the grounds of appeal. The city council shall, within five days after the receipt of the notice of appeal, fix a date and time for the hearing of the appeal and after due notice to the parties at interest, have a hearing on the appeal within ten days of the date the notice of appeal was received by the city and decide the same within a reasonable time. 
(f)  The city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative shall have the power and authority to reinstate any sewerage permit or allow the use of the city's water and sewer service if the person who had been violating the provisions of this chapter shall discontinue and cease such violations. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 7, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-7. - Complaints; adjustments. 
(a)  If the consumer believes his bill to be in error, he shall present his claim, in person, at the city hall before the bill becomes delinquent. Such claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as heretofore provided. The consumer may pay such bill under protest and said payment shall not prejudice his claim. 
(b)  Water meters will be tested at the request of the consumer. However, if the meter does not over-register beyond three percent of the correct volume, the consumer that made the request shall pay to the city the actual cost of making the test, which shall be billed to the consumer with the next water bill sent out by the city. If the meter is found to over-register beyond three percent of the correct volume, no charge will be made. 
(c)  If the seal of a meter is broken by other than the city's representative or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the consumer shall pay an amount estimated from the record of his previous bills and/or from other proper data. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 8, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-8. - Location of mains or conduits. 
No person shall hereafter lay any main pipe for water or sewage, or any conduit for any purpose, in any street within four feet on each side of the centerline of any sewer, unless with the permission of the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 9, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-9. - Fees. 
In addition to such payments or deposits as a petitioner may be required to make in connection with a water extension project, a petitioner shall also be required to pay water cut-on fees and other fees which the city council may from time to time establish. Such fees shall be paid in advance of water service being provided. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 10, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-10. - Minimum charges. 
(a)  The minimum charges, as provided in section 50-1, shall be made for each connection. Water furnished for a given lot shall be used on that lot only. Except for fire protection, the city shall not, under any circumstance, furnish water free of charge to anyone. 
(b)  A consumer using city water, or water from any other source, to fill a swimming pool of the consumer shall not be assessed the minimum charges for sewer service for the water used in the pool so long as said water is not discharged into the sewer system of the city. Each consumer claiming a swimming pool sewer charge exception shall certify in writing to the city clerk or other proper representative of the city the amount of water used in the swimming pool, the date the pool was filled, and that the swimming pool water has not been discharged into the sewer system of the city in order to qualify for the exception. The city council or a duly authorized representative shall make the final determination as to whether a consumer qualifies for the exception. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 11, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-11. - City's responsibility and liability. 
(a)  The city shall run a service line from its distribution line to the property line where the distribution line exists or is to be constructed and runs immediately adjacent and parallel to the property to be served. No charges, other than the fees referred to in sections 50-2 and 50-3, will be made for a five-eighths inch and three-quarters inch meter. A greater charge will be made for a meter of larger dimensions as outlined in section 50-3. 
(b)  The city may make connections to service other properties not adjacent to its lines upon payment of reasonable costs for the extensions of its distribution lines as may be required to render such service. 
(c)  The city may install its meter at or near the property line or, at the city's option, on the consumer's property within three feet of the property line. 
(d)  The city reserves the right to refuse service unless the consumer's lines or pipings are installed in such a manner as to prevent cross connections or backflow. 
(e)  Under normal conditions, the consumer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of service by the city. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 12, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-12. - Consumer's responsibility and liability. 
(a)  Water furnished by the city shall be used for consumption by the consumer, members of his household and employees only. The consumer shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use said water. Water shall not be used for irrigation, fire protection, nor other purposes, except when water is available in sufficient quantity without interfering with the regular domestic consumption in the area served. Disregard for this rule shall be sufficient cause for refusal and/or discontinuance of service. 
(b)  Where a meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a consumer, a suitable place shall be provided by the consumer therefor, unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. 
(c)  The consumer shall furnish and maintain a private cutoff valve on the consumer's side of the meter. 
(d)  The consumer's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the consumer at the consumer's expense, in a safe and efficient manner, and in accordance with the sanitary regulations of the state health department. 
(e)  In order to be received as a consumer and entitled to receive water from the city's water system, all applicants must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the city's water system. All applicants, by becoming consumers of the city, covenant and agree that, so long as they continue to be consumers of the city, they will not permit the connection of any private wells on their property to the city's water system. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 13, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-13. - Water lines—Size determined by city. 
The size of the water lines to be installed to provide water service shall be determined by the city or its engineers and such determination shall be based on the following factors, among others: 
(1)  The maximum length of the line that will be installed; 
(2)  Possible future extensions of a proposed line; 
(3)  Reasonable estimates of the maximum demands for water service that will be placed on a line; 
(4)  The present or future part the line in question will play in a fire protection program. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 14, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-14. - Same—Installation by city. 
All water lines which are to be made a part of the city water distribution system shall be installed by the city or its duly authorized agent and such lines shall be installed in accordance with such specifications as the city shall require and such lines when installed shall be the property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 15, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-15. - Access to premises and extensions of system. 
(a)  Duly authorized agents of the city shall have access at all hours to the premises of the consumer for the purpose of installing or removing city property, inspecting piping, reading and testing meters, or for any other purpose in connection with the water service and its facilities, and the sewer service and its facilities. 
(b)  The city and any duly authorized employees of the city, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties subject to this chapter at any time without prior notice for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, testing and copying any records required to be kept in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The city or its representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(c)  Extensions to the system may be made when the consumer shall grant or convey, or shall cause to be granted or conveyed, to the city a permanent easement of right-of-way across any property traversed by the water and sewer lines. Any extension to the system, whereby the city must acquire the right-of-way or easements, or both, shall only be done when authorized by the city council. 
(d)  The city and any duly authorized employees of the city, bearing proper credentials and identifications, shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the water or sewage works, or both, lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on such easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 16, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-16. - Taps by other than authorized persons prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an employee of the city in the performance of his duties as such, to tap into or make any opening in connection with the water mains or water lines of the city. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 17, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-17. - Separate meter requirements. 
(a)  Each lot, tract or parcel of land to be served by the city water system within or without the city limits shall be served through its own individual water meter. No restrictions shall be placed on the number or type of units served by said meter except as outlined herein. 
(b)  Each multifamily dwelling unit within or without the city limits shall be served by a separate water meter. No multifamily dwelling unit shall be served water through any meter through which water is furnished to another structure, building or dwelling unit. 
(c)  Each unit of a retail development which is intended to, or could, house separate units shall be served through its own individual water meter. 
(d)  Each unit of a single-story, multiunit, commercial or industrial development which is intended to, or could, house separate units shall be served through its own individual water meter. 
(e)  This section shall not apply to those lots, tracts, parcels of land, and dwelling units where water service is currently served by a single or master meter by the approval of the city council prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. The city council, in its discretion, based upon a showing of need by the applicant and sufficient security for the anticipated fees, may grant master meters to applicants. Said master meters shall be charged at a rate determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 18, 12-20-1993; Ord. No. 461, § 1, 12-15-2011 ) 
Sec. 50-18. - Multiple use where water service is served by a single or master meter. 
This section shall not apply existing developments currently served by a master meter prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. The city council, in its discretion, based upon a showing of need by the applicant and sufficient security for the anticipated fees, may grant master meters to applicants. Said master meters shall be charged at a rate determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 19, 12-20-1993; Ord. No. 461, § 2, 12-15-2011 ) 
Sec. 50-19. - Property owner liable for charges, procedure when tenant fails to pay. 
For nonresidential property, the property owner, in every instance where city water is used for nonresidential property, shall be liable to the city for the water or sewer charges, or both, in the amount fixed in this chapter, and if his nonresidential tenant shall fail to pay the charges when presented, then the bill shall be presented to the property owner or his agent, and on his failure or refusal to the pay the same, the water or sewer, or both, shall be at once cut off from his premises and no connection shall be made with such premises until all arrears, together with the cost of the connection shall have been paid to the city clerk. However, no property owner of single or multifamily residential property (including rental residential units) shall be liable for the indebtedness of a prior owner, prior occupant, or prior leasee, to the city for water or sewer services, or both, previously furnished to such residential premises. 
(Ord. No. 100-A, § 1, 1-17-1995) 
Sec. 50-20. - Discontinuance of service, notice required; no continuous flow of water, exception. 
Any person wishing to discontinue the use of water supplied from the waterworks must give notice at the city hall, and they will be charged for the water until such notice. No continuous flow of water will be allowed, unless a special rate is fixed or a meter used. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 21, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-21. - Consumer to connect and provide fixtures. 
Persons taking water must keep their own water pipes, and all fixtures connected therewith, in good repair and protected from frost. They must provide a stopcock and wastecock, arranged so that the water can be drawn from them whenever and wherever there is danger of freezing. Water will not be furnished to any premises not provided with a stopcock and wastecock. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 22, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-22. - Responsibility for leaks and the expense incurred. 
All leaks which occur on the discharge side of the water meter are the responsibility of the property owner and not the water department of the city. Responsibility of the water department to maintain and repair water lines ends at the meter outlet couplings, and customers will be charged for water consumed due to any leak on the customer's side of the meter. Sewer charges may be subject to adjustment, provided the water department receives an affidavit from a licensed plumber, stating a leak existed and was repaired. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 23, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-23. - Buildings connected to water mains; plumbing systems in conformance with plumbing code. 
Every building, dwelling or other structure which is connected to the water mains of the city shall have installed therein plumbing systems, both water and sewer, in conformance with the terms and provisions of the plumbing code of the city and such plumbing systems shall meet all of the terms, specifications, requirements and conditions of the plumbing code. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 24, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-24. - Connections to water mains in accordance with the plumbing code. 
All connections to the water mains of the city shall be made in accordance with and undergo the inspections and tests as set forth in the plumbing code of the city and subject to payment of all inspection fees and other deposits, fees and charges provided therein and in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 25, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-25. - Application of sections 50-23 and 50-24. 
The requirements of sections 50-23 and 50-24 shall apply to additions, remodeling or other changes in the plumbing systems of existing structures as well as to new construction, and to structures located without the limits of the city as well as to those structures located within such limits. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 26, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-26. - City to furnish water during construction of new buildings, compliance with sections 50-23 and 50-24. 
During the construction of new buildings, dwellings and other structures, connections may be made and water furnished by the city and the requirements of sections 50-23 and 50-24 need not be complied with during such construction, but upon the completion of such construction, then the connection shall be cut off and water shall not be furnished until the requirements of sections 50-23 and 50-24 have been complied with. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 27, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-27. - Consumer to conform to city cross connection and backflow prevention requirements. 
All persons connected to or proposing to connect to the city public water supply system shall install and maintain a building water conveyance system which minimizes cross connections between potable and nonpotable water flows. As to the installation of new systems, or upon the alteration or improvement to an existing system, or where necessary to maintain the purity of the potable water within the city public water supply system, the consumer shall install and maintain backflow valves or devices designed to totally eliminate the hazard of backflow or back siphonage of nonpotable waters into the potable water system. Such backflow and back-siphonage prevention devices shall be of design and installation to conform with the requirements of this chapter. Within and without the corporate limits of the city, the city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative of the utility department shall have the authority independent of the respective plumbing inspector to ensure that all consumers have installed and maintained adequate backflow and back-siphonage protection insofar as is necessary to protect the public water supply. This authority shall include the review, inspection and approval of new installation or alterations and the periodic review of existing systems. At the discretion of the city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative, it may delegate this authority to the respective plumbing inspector or the chief building inspector. Such delegation does not terminate the right of the city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative to make or have made independent inspections. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 28, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-28. - Fire sprinkler mains; double detector check valves required. 
All water mains within or without the city limits, constructed for the purpose of providing water to a fire sprinkler system, shall have a double detector check valve installed in line. The valve shall be installed in a concrete vault constructed as close to the city water main as is possible. The vault shall be constructed solely for the purpose of housing the valve and shall be approved by the city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative. Provision, construction and maintenance of the double detector check valve installation shall be the responsibility of the owner and/or consumer. The rate schedule for water service for fire protection services shall be in the amounts fixed in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 29, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-29. - Authority to disconnect service. 
(a)  Whenever the city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative determines that a person is violating or has violated the cross connection provisions of this chapter and determines that the violation of such provisions will cause immediate damage or harm to the treatment process, equipment or treatment and distribution facilities of the city, or that the violation endangers the public health, safety or general welfare of the community, the city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative shall have the power and authority to immediately terminate that person's water service until that person has ceased the violation. 
(b)  Charges for any discontinuance or resumption of water service shall be in the amounts fixed in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 30, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-30. - Compliance with article provisions required. 
Water service shall not be extended to developed or undeveloped property either within the city or outside the city except in conformity with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 31, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-31. - Water lines to be placed within public rights-of-way or public easements. 
Water lines may be placed within public easements established for such purpose or within the right-of-way lines of streets and roads which have been certified as being a part of the public road or street system of either the city or county. The city council may authorize the placement of lines within other properly acquired rights-of-way or easements, or both. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 32, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-32. - Streets to be at final grade. 
A water line shall not be placed within a street right-of-way until the street for which such right-of-way was created has been constructed to final grade. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 33, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-33. - New subdivisions. 
The following rules shall govern the extension of water service into new subdivisions: 
(1)  Subdivisions within the city. A subdivision established within the city shall comply with all applicable provisions of this chapter before it shall be eligible to receive water service from the city. 
(2)  Subdivisions outside the city limits. From and after the date that a governmental jurisdiction adopts subdivision regulations for areas outside the corporate limits of the city a subdivision thereafter established in such areas shall comply with all applicable provisions of such subdivision regulations before it shall be eligible to receive water service from the city. In the event subdivision regulations are not adopted for areas outside the city, then all subdivision lots established after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived and which are seeking City water service shall comply with the lot area requirements found in the city's zoning and subdivision ordinances and regulations. In such cases, a certification of such compliance shall be obtained from the proper authority. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 34, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-34. - Service prohibited lots creating potential health and sanitation problems. 
When the lots requesting water service have been laid out in such a manner as might cause health and sanitation problems to develop when such lots are developed, the city water service shall only be extended to such lots after the owners of such lots have first devised a method of eliminating the danger of health and sanitation problems which shall meet with the approval of the county health department. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 35, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-35. - Maintenance and renewal projects—Compliance with provisions. 
All maintenance and renewal projects for either the water treatment and distribution system or the sewerage collection and treatment system which are not regulated by other chapters shall conform to the applicable provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 36, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-36. - Same—Approval of city council required. 
Before an extension, renewal or maintenance project shall be undertaken, the city council shall be required to authorize the project. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 37, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-37. - Same—Application. 
Application for a project shall be in the form of a work order request, with the following conditions: 
(1)  A work order request shall be prepared in triplicate and shall be signed by the city council. 
(2)  The work order request shall contain all the pertinent facts about the proposed project and shall include a certification that sufficient funds are available to finance the project. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 38, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-38. - Permission required to make connections. 
No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the chief building inspector for residential or commercial services and industrial services. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 39, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-39. - Classes of building sewer permits. 
(a)  There are two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  Residential; and 
(2)  Service to establishments producing commercial or industrial wastes. 
(b)  The city, the mayor, or any duly authorized representative may require a user of sewer services to provide information needed to determine compliance with this section. These requirements may include: 
(1)  Wastewaters discharge peak rate and volume over a specified time period; 
(2)  Chemical analyses of wastewaters; 
(3)  Information on raw materials, processes and products affecting wastewater volume and quality; 
(4)  Quantity and disposition of specific liquid, sludge, oil, solvent or other materials important to sewer use control; 
(5)  A plot plan of sewers on the user's property showing sewer and pretreatment facility location; 
(6)  Details of wastewater pretreatment facilities; 
(7)  Details of systems to prevent and control the losses of materials through spills to the city sewer. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 40, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-40. - Installation costs borne by owner. 
All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 41, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-41. - Separate sewer connections for every building. 
A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be construed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway. The front building sewer may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer, but the city shall not be liable for any damage caused by or resulting from any such single connection aforementioned. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 42, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-42. - Old sewer connections to meet requirements. 
Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, upon examination and test by the chief building inspector, to meet all requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 43, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-43. - Construction to conform to codes. 
The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. All work shall conform to all applicable regulations of the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials and Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, as amended, shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 44, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-44. - Sewer to be below basement floor. 
Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 45, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-45. - Storm drains not to be connected to sanitary sewer. 
No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer unless such connection is approved by the city, the mayor, or duly authorized representative for purposes of disposal of polluted surface drainage. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 46, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-46. - Sewer connections to conform to codes. 
The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials and the Water Pollution Control Federal Manual of Practice No. 9, as amended. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the described procedures and materials must be approved before installation. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 47, 12-20-1993) 
Sec. 50-47. - Cleanout required at point of connection. 
(a)  A sanitary sewer cleanout shall be installed on all building sewers as near to the point at which city maintenance begins as is possible. This point shall be the curbline, the right-of-way line, the property line, or the easement line, whichever is applicable. Such cleanout shall be six inches in diameter and shall have a cleanout plug.
